Western Digital (WDC) filed for arbitration Sunday to prevent partner Toshiba from selling its stake in their memory chip joint venture, a move that would delay any transaction. Hard drive maker Western Digital, has a joint venture with the Japanese tech giant via its acquisition of flash memory maker SanDisk, says it must have a say."Toshiba's attempt to spin out its joint venture interests into an affiliate and then sell that affiliate is explicitly prohibited without SanDisk's consent," said Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan in a statement.Toshiba is trying to shed assets to raise enough cash to stay afloat, with U.S. nuclear unit Westinghouse filing for bankruptcy in March. Possible bidders for Toshiba's chip business include Broadcom (AVGO), SK Hynix and Apple (AAPL) iPhone maker Hon Hai Precision Industry — or Foxconn.Broadcom cleared a 227.85 buy point last week, rising to 235.90 on Friday, still in range. Broadcom, which is also an Apple supplier.Western Digital has mulled making its own bid for Toshiba's JV stake, perhaps in conjunction with a quasi-state Japanese entities. Western Digital rose out of buy range following its solid earnings and strong guidance last month.

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) hiked its stake in Apple (AAPL) by more than 125% to 129.4 million shares in the first quarter, and made modest changes to its airlines holdings while avoiding Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP), which went public in March.Meanwhile, Soros Fund Management bought 1.7 million shares of Snap, joining David Tepper's Appaloosa Management and Dan Loeb's Third Point. Soros also dissolved his firm's positions in Amazon.com (AMZN) and Delta Air Lines (DAL), and added to its stake in Facebook (FB), according to filings late Monday.David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital trimmed its Apple holdings to 4.2 million shares from 6.1 million in Q4, while more than quadrupling its stake in General Motors (GM) to 55 million shares from 13 million.In Q1, Berkshire grew its American Airlines (AAL) stake to 49.3 million shares, up 8.4% vs. the previous quarter, and its investment in Southwest Airlines (LUV) to 47.7 million, up 10.4%. It trimmed its position in Delta to 55 million shares, down 8.3%, while keeping its holdings in United Airlines (UAL) steady at 28.9 million.The regulatory filing confirmed news from early May that Berkshire's Buffett busily dumped tech giant IBM (IBM) in Q1. It had 64.6 million shares left at quarter-end, down 20%. (Even IBM Retirement Fund's unloaded 70,000 shares of IBM, leaving it with 12,451 IBM shares in Q1, according to the fund's 13F filing on May 10.)Meanwhile, the conglomerate's massive long-term stakes in Coca-Cola (KO), American Express (AXP) and Kraft Heinz (KHC) were left basically unchanged.Buffett had already said Berkshire more than doubled its Apple holdings in Q1, giving it a 2.5% stake in the iPhone maker's outstanding shares. Berkshire initiated a position in Apple, worth $1.1 billion, in Q1 2016 and doubled down on Apple as the year progressed.By contrast, Appaloosa Management slashed its stake in 2017's best-performing Dow component Apple by a third, to 300,000 shares, and trimmed Facebook by 12.6%, to 1.9 million shares in Q1, according to filings from Friday. The company also scooped up 100,000 shares of Snap, which tanked 17.5% last week on a dismal debut earnings reports following its March IPO.Similarly, Third Point exited its 1.85 million-share stake in Apple during Q1, while buying 2.25 million shares of Snap.Shares of Berkshire closed up 0.3% at 163.76 on the stock market today. Apple dipped 0.3%, down from Friday's fresh record high, and Snap rallied 8.4%, after last week's plunge. Facebook eased 0.1%, and IBM added 0.7%.Among Appaloosa's other notable moves, the fund entirely liquidated its massive stakes in two troubled stocks: chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) and retailer J.C. Penney (JCP).Appaloosa added a 1.6 million-share stake in Symantec (SYMC), which was leading a cybersecurity stock rally Monday on the heels of a global ransomware attack. Appaloosa also raised its Western Digital (WDC) stake by 16.1% to 1.3 million shares.But the hedge fund's biggest bet seems to be on an American industrial renaissance. It opened positions of roughly half a million shares each in AK Steel (AKS) and Nucor (NUE), while upping ArcelorMittal (MT) by more than 410%, to nearly 5 million shares.Other hefty new positions included Bank of America (BAC) and CBS (CBS) (8.8 million and 1.0 million shares, respectively).Third Point's other moves include adding to positions in T-Mobile (TMUS), Salesforce (CRM), Qualcomm and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD).The fund closed a small stake in Goldman Sachs (GS), and reduced holdings in Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase (JPM).Late Friday, Trian Fund Management also disclosed bigger positions in General Electric (GE) and Procter & Gamble (PG) and a smaller stake in DuPont (DD).RELATED:What Will Berkshire Filing Show As Loeb Cuts Facebook, Apple Stakes?Why Buffett Still Isn't Sure If He'd Buy Amazon, Alphabet Stock Now

Americans want smarter devices, homes, factories and cities, so STMicroelectronics (STM) has remade itself to deliver the smarts.One of Europe's largest semiconductor companies, STMicro is growing with red-hot demand for the chips needed for intelligent devices. Some on Wall Street seem convinced the outlook is promising for the venerable, 30-year-old Swiss firm whose stock struggled for more than a decade and a half following the dot-com boom and bust."The outlook for 2018 is pretty much a historical high," Tristan Gerra, a semiconductor analyst for R.W. Baird, told Investor's Business Daily."(STMicro) has methodically shut down businesses losing money or just breaking even, such as memory chips and cellphone chips," Gerra said. "Now the result is you have a company that is much leaner that only has products that are profitable."STMicro has benefited from relentless smartphone innovations, connected home devices and wearable tech gadgets, as well as emerging opportunities in the automotive and industrial sectors.A massive shift toward greener, safer and self-driving cars is one powerful engine of growth. The industrial Internet of Things — which connects machines to one another and the cloud, while harnessing the power of Big Data analytics to make factories more efficient — is another.STMicro stock has vaulted 125% in the past year. That is more than three times the return of the PHLX SOX Semiconductor Sector Index — dominated by U.S. giants Nvidia (NVDA), Intel (INTC) and Qualcomm (QCOM) — over the same period.Gerra believes STMicro stock has room to run despite the monster moves it already has made, rising to levels not seen in a decade. He has a price target of 20, which represents an upside of roughly 14%. Shares climbed into buy territory Thursday and have kept climbing since then. Shares ended the regular trading session Tuesday up 1.7% to 17.77.STMicro's surging profits and margins come as the firm has raised its capital expenditures to $1.25 billion to $1.3 billion, citing new products and higher demand, while alluding to design wins. Many investors and analysts understand the latter to mean the eagerly awaited 10th anniversary iPhone from Apple (AAPL).STMicro's 3D sensors are expected to power the upcoming iPhone's standout new feature: advanced facial-recognition technologies that may allow users to unlock devices and authenticate payments in a more seamless way, experts say.Improving fundamentals and a robust product portfolio make the stock "well-positioned for a continued recovery with significantly less cyclicality going forward," Gerra said in a recent note, while highlighting the potential for further revenue momentum.Analyst views call for STMicro earnings to more than quadruple to 83 cents a share for fiscal 2017 from 19 cents for 2016, according to Zacks Investment Research. For 2018, that's projected to reach $1.10 a share, then rise to $1.16 in 2019, Zacks says.STMicro holds one of the broadest product portfolios in the chipmaking industry, according to investment research firm Morningstar Inc. And the firm is seeing strong growth in bookings across all its product lines and global regions."We are firing on all cylinders," STMicro Executive Vice President Bob Krysiak told IBD. "We have great pipelines in smartphones, automotives and across the mass-market space."Besides Apple, major customers include Cisco (CSCO), Seagate (STX) and Western Digital (WDC), as well as Asian smartphone makers Huawei and Samsung. Its products end up in everything from cars and smartphones to drones, welding equipment, solar kits, thermostats and consumer electronics.Its micro-mirror MEMS chips in the Amazon (AMZN) Echo Look and near field communication (NFC) chips in the Samsung Galaxy S8 show how the company is innovating and pursuing new lines of growth, according to Gerra. NFC chips allow smart devices to talk to one another when brought physically together, such as pay card readers.The smartphone remains king for the company, notwithstanding slowing sales across the industry."It's a big market that continues to innovate every year," Krysiak said. "Smartphone makers depend on us suppliers to provide the innovation."STMicro has been making strategic moves in this segment. Abandoning its dated Nokia and Blackberry businesses years ago, it switched its focus to phone sensors, power management, security, NFC and other wireless technologies.Its FlightSense technology opens the door to the next generation of proximity sensors. For instance, it helps smartphone cameras focus automatically with much greater accuracy.The biggest opportunities may still be ahead. Smartphones have assumed a role as a central device in the larger Internet of Things, becoming as indispensable to industrial end markets as to the average consumer, Krysiak says.IBD'S TAKE: As IBD Stock Checkup notes, STMicro's stellar ratings for Earnings Per Share growth and Relative Price Strength help it earn a spot among the top five stocks in its industry group.Other massive opportunities are seen in autos and factories. The company has gone well beyond its traditional supplies to the automotive industry.Its positioning and car-to-car communication technologies are making self-driving cars possible. It has partnered with Israeli vision-tech pioneer Mobileye (MBLY) on groundbreaking active safety systems. And with vehicles becoming "almost an internet device," in Krysiak's words, and electrified powertrains on the rise, the silicon content of cars has ballooned.STMicro calls these emerging automotive trends "smart driving" and now averages 36 parts per vehicle produced in the world, up from 24 just a few years ago."Smart driving is just starting," said Krysiak, who believes the opportunity lies not just in intelligent vehicles themselves, but the entire infrastructure — of power charging systems, parking structures and the like — needed to leverage all that processing power.STMicro also is infusing technology into a sector sometimes viewed as boring — industrials.STMicro chips have made data centers more energy efficient, helped robots become more situation-aware and precise, and brought augmented reality and touchless interfaces to industrial assets."The last bastion of change in the digitization of everything will be the factory floor," Krysiak said. "We are bringing our vision systems and processing systems there, all leveraging cloud-computing technologies."STMicro posted net revenue of $6.97 billion in 2016. It spent roughly 19% of that on R&D investments, amid cutthroat industry competition to keep rolling out what the firm describes as "significantly cheaper, smaller, faster, more reliable and embedded" products.For fiscal 2017, STMicro is targeting $8 billion in revenue and is now guiding to the high end of its previous forecast range of 12.5%-15.5% growth.While many analysts regard STMicro as a well-diversified company with some unique products, they see challenges too. Baird's Gerra notes that it remains a somewhat cyclical company, since it has a manufacturing component.Slowing car sales in the U.S. and China — two of the biggest automotive markets — are a potential challenge in the future too.Morningstar analyst Brian Colello also sees risks tied to STMicro's in-house manufacturing, with the need for further research reinvestments and ongoing capital expenditures potentially weighing on profits.He raises yellow flags about other aspects of its operations.There are concerns about STMicro's "ownership by the French and Italian governments, which raises doubts as to whether it is truly focused on operating efficiency," he wrote in a recent report.Finally, STMicro hasn't developed a massive scale advantage given its size, with gross margins and operating profits "below those of other successful pure-play analog chipmakers," Colello said.RELATED:Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksThe New AmericaChip Stocks & Semiconductor Industry News And Analysis

Disk drive manufacturer Western Digital (WDC) reported quarterly results after the market close Thursday that beat on the bottom line and matched estimates on the top.XWestern Digital reported revenue of $4.8 billion, matching consensus estimates and up 37% from the year-ago quarter. It reported adjusted earnings of $2.93, beating views of $2.81, for its fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30.Western Digital stock was near 92.30, up 0.4% in after-market action in the stock market today. Shares of Western Digital are up 34% this year.Shares of rival disk drive company Seagate Technology (STX) fell hard earlier this week after reporting quarterly results that missed expectations. Seagate is the second largest disk drive maker, behind Western Digital.Western Digital said it generated approximately $1 billion in cash from operations during its fiscal fourth quarter, ending with $6.5 billion in cash and equivalents and marketable securities.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital stock is up 35% this year. The stock has a IBD Composite Rating of 98 out of a possible 99, based on a variety of performance metrics."We operated near the top of our revenue growth model with 7% year-over-year top-line growth on a pro forma basis, and we delivered very healthy margins," said Steve Milligan, Western Digital chief executive, in prepared remarks.Western Digital is engaged in an intense battle with Toshiba over the sale of a chip manufacturing plant that the two jointly run.

The major market indexes sold off in morning trade Wednesday, after a momentary uptick at the starting bell sputtered. All three major indexes — the tech-heavy Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average — declined 0.3%.X Among the Dow industrials, Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) was one of the top performers in the stock market today. The discount chain advanced 0.5% after inking a deal with Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) to link Wal-Mart store accounts to the Google Express shopping service.On the downside, Home Depot (HD) fell 1.5% in sympathy with home improvement competitor Lowe's (LOW), which missed Q2 forecasts early Wednesday. Lowe's fell over 5%, and is consolidating under its 50- and 200-day lines. Shares of Home Depot are building a flat base, but suffered a setback last week amid concerns about slowing growth.Within the S&P 500, hard-drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) declined almost 4%. Rival Western Digital (WDC) advanced over 2% as it attempts to reclaim its 50-day line where it has been trading since July 28.Among companies reporting earnings, Salesforce.com (CRM) reversed from losses to rise 1.7% after the enterprise software provider missed its current-quarter billings guidance. The stock remains in the 5% buy zone from its 92.09 flat-base entry.Meanwhile, American Eagle (AEO) trimmed its gains to 5% early Wednesday after the company reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings results. The retailer has been stuck in a downtrend for about a year. Shares were getting above their 50-day line, but remain stuck under the 200-day line.After the close, home furnishings retailer Williams-Sonoma (WSM) will join HP (HPQ) in reporting their quarterly earnings figures. Williams-Sonoma is stuck in a downtrend, while HP is constructing a cup with handle with a 19.68 buy point.Among leading stocks, PayPal (PYPL) declined over 1%. The payment processor has been one of the top stocks in the stock market and is up almost 10% from a 55.24 flat-base entry.Within the IBD 50, Essent Group (ESNT) moved up almost 2% as it made another attempt to recapture a 39.60 flat-base buy point.On the downside, Autohome (ATHM) fell 1%, but still has an over-80% gain from a 36.11 cup-shaped base.RELATED:Salesforce.com Earnings Beat, But Billings Outlook Below ViewsDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisHP, Lowe's, Williams-Sonoma Top Wednesday's Investing Action Plan

Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite rose Thursday morning ahead of key U.S. economic data and amid a report showing Chinese manufacturing contracting. Four recent tech breakouts — Apple (AAPL) iPhone supplier Analog Devices (ADI), Micron Technology (MU), Marvell Technology (MRVL) and Paylocity (PCTY) — remain in buy range.X During Wednesday's session, the major averages reversed lower as oil prices fell and bank stocks tumbled. But while financials remained weak, the S&P 500 and other key index closed with slim losses, capping a solid tech-led month of May.Dow industrials futures rose fractionally vs. fair value. S&P 500 futures were up 0.1% while Nasdaq 100 futures climbed climbed 0.3%.Futures briefly pared most of their gains following the private-sector Caixin survey that showed Chinese manufacturing activity contracting for the first time in nearly a year. That follows slow-but-steady growth from official government data, out earlier in the week, that focuses more on state-owned enterprises.China's Shanghai composite slid 0.5% Thursday. Japan's Nikkei advanced 1.1%, ending a recent slide.In the U.S., investors will get the ISM manufacturing index, the ADP employment report and domestic auto sales for May, ahead of Friday's key jobs report.IBD'S TAKE: Chinese regulators, worried about soaring credit growth, are starting to crack down, having an impact on the world's No. 2 economy in short order. That's the focus of our latest cover story: "Here's Why China's Latest Growth Scare Should Worry You."Analog shares rose 2.4% to 84.80 on Tuesday, just moving beyond an 84.34 buy point. On Wednesday, the Apple iPhone supplier shares shot up as high as 90.49, but closed at 85.76, just a 1.1% gain and near session lows. That's not great action, and investors should be cautious. However, shares are well within the 5% chase zone from the entry point.What sparked Wednesday's big move? Analog Devices reported strong earnings and bullish guidance before the market open, though revenue was essentially in line.Analog Devices has been touted as a likely big winner from the upcoming Apple iPhone 8, due out later this year.As for Apple itself, shares dipped 0.6% on Wednesday, continuing to trade tightly over the last few weeks, close to record highs. Apple does not have a potential buy point current after a long run.Analog Devices has a best-possible 99 Composite Rating, which means it outperforms 99% of all stocks based on a variety of IBD proprietary fundamental and technical data. Big-time winners tend to have Composite Ratings of 95 or more near the start of their runs.Paylocity, the lone non-chipmaker highlighted here, is a cloud-based human resources software firm.Paylocity cleared a 45.71 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern on May 25, and shares have remained above the entry since then. Shares fell intraday Wednesday but closed up 0.2% to 46.85.Other cloud-based HR software peers include Paycom (PAYC) and Workday (WDAY). Paycom has been hovering around a three-weeks-tight follow-on buy point, while Workday is modestly extended from a breakout. Workday, which competes against Oracle (ORCL) and SAP (SAP), is expected to report a 220% EPS gain late Thursday.Paylocity has a 97 Composite Rating.The memory chipmaker cleared a 29.97 flat base buy point on Tuesday, then edged up 0.2% to 30.77 on Wednesday, still well within buy range. Industry demand and pricing is strong, boosting profits of other memory chip players such as Samsung Electronics and Western Digital (WDC).Micron's CR Rating is an 89, reflecting a poor run of earnings until recently. Memory chip makers' fortunes tend to be highly cyclical, so stocks often start to move on indications of improving industry fundamentals before big earnings come in. Micron is reporting strong results now.Marvell cleared a 16.82 buy point on May 25, then reported strong earnings after the closing bell that session. The next day, shares popped to just out of buying range, but shares have come back modestly this week to 17.24 on Wednesday.Marvell has a 92 Composite Rating.RELATED:The Big Picture: Techs Hot, But 2 Broad Sectors Are StrugglingHere's Why Bank Stocks Broke Key SupportThis Top Software Firm Has Flipped From Losses: 220% EPS Gain Seen ThursdayChip Stocks And Semiconductor Industry News3 Tech Leaders Near Highs As Earnings Loom: Investing Action Plan

The stock market headed lower early Tuesday following three-day Memorial Day weekend. The S&P 500 index and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively, while the Nasdaq dipped nearly 0.1%.Among the Dow industrials, Verizon (VZ) paced the advancers with a 1.1% rise. Fast-food chain McDonald's (MCD) fell 0.2% despite having its price target hiked at Barclay's to 164 from 155. The firm maintained its outperform rating amid its raised expectations for the company's digital and delivery efforts.In early trading, the blue chip's laggards include financial component Goldman Sachs (GS) and energy components Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM). The global investment bank fell 1.9%, while the oil giants fell 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively, as oil prices slipped more than 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate just above $49 a barrel.On the S&P 500, computer security firm Symantec (SYMC) rose 2% after being upgraded to overweight from equal-weight at Barclay's. Shares were attempting to reclaim their 50-day line after piercing it on May 17.On the downside, energy names found themselves at the bottom of the S&P 500's performers amid a 1.4% decline in the price of crude oil. Devon Energy (DVN) and Valero Energy (VLO) fell 3.1% and 1.3%, respectively.Among other leading stocks, Micron Technology (MU) jumped more than 2% as it surged above a 29.97 flat-base buy point. Fellow data storage firms Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) rose 2.3% and 1.5%, respectively.Nvidia (NVDA) rose 2.8% as it set a fresh record high, while e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) briefly broke above the vaunted 1000 price level, rising 0.3%.Among analyst actions, former highflier Ambarella (AMBA) fell 6.5% after being downgraded to sector weight from overweight at Pacific Crest. Over the last eight weeks, the stock has made a strong comeback on its way to building the right side of a potential cup-base. Meanwhile, Tesla (TSLA) was initiated at hold by Independent Research. Shares of the electric automaker soared over 2% to reach a new high, extending its three-day winning streak.Action in the IBD 50 was mostly positive after the open, but several leaders found themselves under pressure early Tuesday. Recent issue Floor & Decor (FND) dropped nearly 7% after last week's IPO-base breakout. Shares remain above the 39.59 entry. China education stocks New Oriental Education (EDU) and TAL Education (TAL) fell 3.5% each.On the upside, Match Group (MTCH) and Ichor (ICHR) moved up 2.9% and 3.4%, respectively.RELATED:Analysts Tout McDonald's, Yum But Cut Ambarella, AutoZoneSnap Seeks Support, But These 3 Hot IPOs Are Near Buy ZonesDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisWeek In Review: Stocks Hit Highs On FANGs; Oil Dives After OPEC; Best Buy, Ulta Shine

Data storage company Western Digital (WDC) hit a record high Friday in reaction to fiscal third-quarter earnings that beat on the top and bottom lines, as did its outlook for the fourth quarter.Several analysts raised their price target on Western Digital, including Needham analyst Richard Kugele. He raised his target on the shares to 138 from 100, with a strong buy rating.Western Digital stock rose 3.9% to 89.07 in the stock market today. Its intraday high Friday was 91. The company is in IBD's Tech Leaders screen.After the market close Thursday, Western Digital reported adjusted earnings of $2.39 a share, up 77% year over year, on a 64% increase in revenue to $4.6 billion. Both sales and profits soundly beat estimates for the period ended March 31. The results include revenue from Western Digital's $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk, which closed in May a year ago."Favorable trends across all of their markets drove an impressive performance at Western Digital for fiscal Q3," Kugele wrote in a research note Friday. "However, all of this goodness pales in comparison to the guidance for fiscal Q4 and for 2017."Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX), and is also now a formidable player in chip-based flash storage, with its SanDisk acquisition. Western Digital is reportedly considering buying a stake in the flash-memory business of Toshiba. Western Digital and Toshiba jointly operate a flash-memory plant in Japan.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital sports a strong IBD Composite Rating of 93, meaning it has outperformed 93% all stocks over the past six months, based on a variety of metrics.Western Digital is benefiting from tight supplies of a new generation of memory chips, known as NAND. Along with Seagate Technology, both are benefiting from stability in the disk drive market.Seagate, however, reported quarterly results Wednesday morning that missed revenue estimates, dragging the stock down. Seagate dipped 0.4% on Friday, losing more than 12% for the week.Mizuho analyst Vijay Rakesh raised his price target on Western Digital to 105 from 92 and maintained a buy rating."Western Digital reported a solid March quarter above consensus as it pulls ahead of its peer with solid execution," Rakesh wrote in a research note Friday.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani raised his price target on Western Digital to 115 from 96, with an outperform rating."Western Digital reported a blowout quarter with plenty of positives," Daryanani wrote in a research note.For the fiscal fourth quarter, the company forecast revenue of approximately $4.8 billion, vs. estimates of $4.6 billion. It forecast adjusted earnings in the range of $2.55 to $2.65, vs. estimates of $2.14. RELATED:Western Digital Gets Positive Reviews On 'Crisp Execution'Western Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

Teradata (TDC) saw a welcome improvement to its Relative Strength (RS) Rating on Tuesday, with an increase from 66 to 71. X This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily tracks market leadership with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The rating shows how a stock's price behavior over the last 52 weeks stacks up against all the other stocks in our database. Over 100 years of market history reveals that the stocks that go on to make the biggest gains often have an RS Rating of over 80 in the early stages of their moves. See if Teradata can continue to show renewed price strength and hit that benchmark. The stock is building a consolidation with a 33.42 entry. See if the stock can clear the breakout price in heavy trading. The company reported negative growth for both sales and earnings last quarter. Disk-drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) was down hard Tuesday after reporting fiscal fourth-quarter results before the market open that missed expectations.XSeagate reported revenue of $2.4 billion, down 9% from the year-ago quarter and missing the consensus estimate of $2.56 billion. It reported adjusted earnings of 65 cents per share, well below the consensus of 99 cents and down 6%.Seagate rival Western Digital (WDC) reports quarterly results after the market close Thursday. The consensus estimate for Western Digital is adjusted earnings of $2.83, up 258% from the year-ago quarter, and revenue of $4.8 billion, up 37%. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate and is also now a formidable player in chip-based flash storage, with its SanDisk acquisitionSeagate stock fell 16.5% to 33.20 on the stock market today. Western Digital stock slipped 0.9% to 93.75.IBD'S TAKE: Seagate has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 62 out of a possible 99, while Western Digital has a strong Composite Rating of 98. Check out the IBD 50 for a screen of leading growth stocks showing strong relative price strength and top-notch fundamentals.Seagate said its board of directors has unanimously voted to appoint Dave Mosley, Seagate's president and chief operating officer, as chief executive effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Seagate CEO Steve Luczo. Mosley was also appointed to Seagate's board of directors, effective July 25."Although the near-term dynamics of technology shifts present demand variations for the storage industry from time to time, we continue to see growing storage demand in the long-run driven by the proliferation of data growth from new technologies, emerging industries, and growing businesses," Luczo said in prepared remarks.Memory-chip maker Micron Technology (MU) fell hard on Tuesday in the wake of earnings reports by Seagate and South Korean memory-chip maker SK Hynix. It was down 5.6% to 29.90. It cut through its 50-day moving average.Also down Tuesday is Everspin Technologies (MRAM), a maker of magnetic RAM chips. Everspin fell as low as 17.12 but closed down just 0.9% to 18.31, but below its 50-day line. Everspin stock has fallen for five of the last six trading sessions after hitting an all-time high of 25.39 on July 18. Chandler, Ariz.-based Everspin went public at 8 last October.RELATED:Western Digital Hits Record High After 'Blowout' Earnings, Outlook

Data storage company Western Digital (WDC) after the close Thursday reported quarterly earnings that beat on the top and bottom lines as did its second-quarter outlook, sending the stock up in after-hours trading.Western Digital reported adjusted earnings of $2.39 a share, up 77% year over year and beating the consensus of $2.14. Revenue rose 64% to $4.6 billion, beating the consensus of $4.58 billion, for its fiscal third quarter ended March 31. The results include revenue from Western Digital's $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk, which closed in May a year ago.For the second quarter it forecast revenue of approximately $4.8 billion, vs. estimates of $4.6 billion. It forecast adjusted EPS in the range of $2.55 to $2.65, vs. estimates of $2.14.Shares of the company were up 7%, near 92, in after-hours trading on the stock market today. The stock is up about 85% in the past year.The earnings report follows the disappointing quarterly results of rival Seagate Technology (STX). Seagate reported quarterly earnings after the close Wednesday.Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate, and is also now a formidable player in chip-based flash storage, with its SanDisk acquisition.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital was added to the IBD Leaderboard list of top-performing stocks on March 30. The stock sports a strong IBD Composite Rating of 94, meaning it has outperformed all stocks over the past six months, based on a variety of metrics.Western Digital is reportedly considering buying a stake in the flash-memory business of Toshiba, which needs the funds to cover a looming multibillion-dollar write-down due to an accounting scandal. Western Digital and Toshiba jointly operate a flash-memory plant in Japan.Western Digital generated $1 billion in cash from operations during the third fiscal quarter of 2017, ending with $5.8 billion of total cash and equivalents."We reported strong financial performance in the March quarter, enabled by excellent operational execution by our team in a healthy market environment with good demand for all NAND-based products, as well as for capacity enterprise and client hard drives," said Western Digital Chief Executive Steve Milligan, in prepared remarks with the earnings announcement.RELATED:Western Digital Gets Positive Reviews On 'Crisp Execution'Western Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

XDisk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) reported quarterly results Wednesday morning that missed revenue estimates, dragging the stock down as well as that of rival Western Digital (WDC).Seagate reported revenue of $2.67 billion, up 3% year over year but missing the consensus estimate of $2.69 billion, as polled by Zacks Investment Research. That reversed eight quarters in a row of year-over-year declines.It reported adjusted earnings of $1.10 a share, up 400% year over year and beating the consensus of $1.06, for its fiscal third quarter ended March 31.Seagate stock plunged 16.6% to 42.01 in the stock market today, hitting a three-month low. Western Digital lost 2.6% to 84.61.Western Digital is set to report fiscal third-quarter earnings after the market close Thursday.Seagate and Western Digital have both seen a strong increase in their stock price in the past year as the disk drive industry has stabilized after several years of declines. Western Digital is also benefiting from a shortage of Nand memory chips.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital was added to the IBD Leaderboard list of top-performing stocks on March 30. The stock sports a strong IBD Composite Rating of 94, meaning it has outperformed all stocks over the past six months, based on a variety of metrics.Seagate said it generated $426 million in cash flow from operations and paid cash dividends of $186 million during the quarter. It reported cash and equivalents of $3 billion."The results of our financial performance this quarter reflect a stable demand environment, good operational execution and momentum in the stabilization of our business model," said Steve Luczo, Seagate's chairman and chief executive officer, in comments with the earnings release.RELATED:Western Digital Upgraded As PC Market Stabilizes, Memory Chips Strong

Since the start of the year, the weekly Tech Leaders column has cast a spotlight on numerous companies — right before they staged breakouts to fine gains and handsome profits for savvy investors who aren't afraid of using charts to time their buys. Let's review three of those featured and see how well they're doing. Paycom Software (PAYC) was highlighted in…

There's no shortage of star power in First Trust Nasdaq-100-Technology Sector ETF (QTEC), with Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL) among its holdings.Indeed, the exchange traded fund is a way to gain exposure to the biggest brands in technology, and those stocks are performing well. Because it's culled from the Nasdaq 100 (the largest nonfinancial stocks in the composite), the ETF is predominantly a big-cap fund, with a median market cap of $32 billion.More than 40% of the fund is in chip stocks. About one-fourth is in software, 17% in internet companies and the rest in hardware, services and telecom stocks. The fund's hardware stocks have been shining.Western Digital (WDC) has surged more than 130% from a low in May 2016. The data storage stock broke out of a base March 30 and remains near a 81.77 buy point. Rival Seagate Technology (STX) has risen more than 160% from its May low. Apple may be flagging the past couple of weeks, but shares have rallied about 20% from a breakout past a 118.12 entry in January.The internet components haven't exactly impressed. Alphabet — the parent company of Google — Yahoo (YHOO), Baidu (BIDU), Akamai (AKAM) and NetEase (NTES) have printed mediocre charts for months. Facebook, though, is still trending moderately upward.Despite relative strength in the sector, the ETF's semiconductor stocks have been mixed.What about the sector's outlook? Much depends on consumer reception to new products, such as the next iPhone model, and corporate spending on information technology. Earlier this month, Nomura analysts saw strength in that area."Our early-April survey of 50 global CIOs offered a significantly improved view of 2017 IT spending vs. our October survey," the firm noted. "This suggests the economic and financial upticks since October may prove resilient. The top spending drivers, security and cloud, remain key themes."The tech sector is turning in the third-highest earnings growth rate of 11 S&P sectors at 13.0%, according to FactSet.The 35 companies in the ETF are about evenly distributed in terms of weighting, each accounting for 1.5% to 3.2% of the portfolio. That leaves the fund less exposed to risk from a single holding.The ETF has made an impressive run since it broke out of a long consolidation and started making new highs last July. Today, shares are finding support at the 50-day moving average. That leaves investors with an opportunity to buy shares, although it needs to be treated as a secondary entry, not as favorable as a base breakout. The most recent of those was in November, when First Trust Nasdaq-100-Tech Sector was trading at 51.65.RELATED:Robotics ETF Taps Growth In Manufacturing, Drones, Other AreasThis Cloud-Computing ETF Is Loaded With FANG Stocks

Hard disk and computer storage leader Western Digital (WDC) saw its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating jump to 99 Monday, up from 93 the day before.The upgrade means the stock currently tops 99% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. History shows the top market performers tend to have a 95 or higher score as they launch their major climbs.Western Digital is now extended, trading just above a recent buy zone. See if the stock goes on to offer a new buying opportunity.Jefferies downgraded the data storage company to hold and lowered its price target to 90 from 100, saying "we have a hard time imagining the NAND (flash memory)  market dynamics getting better from here."The stock has an 81 EPS Rating, which means its recent quarterly and longer-term annual earnings growth is outpacing 81% of all stocks.Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A- shows heavy buying by institutional investors, such as mutual funds and pension funds, over the last 13 weeks.The company reported 77% earnings-per-share growth for Q3. That means it's now posted three straight quarters of rising EPS gains. Sales growth increased 65%, up from 47% in the prior report. The company has now posted increasing growth in each of the last four quarters.Western Digital earns the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Computer-Data Storage industry group. Carbonite (CARB) and Intevac (IVAC) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?Analyst Doubts Western Digital 'Dynamics' Can Get Better

Western Digital (WDC)downgraded on competition outlook, Shopify (SHOP) downgraded; Comcast (CMCSA) and China-based Baidu (BIDU) win price target hikes, Autodesk (ADSK) upgraded.Jefferies downgraded data storage company Western Digital to hold and lowered its price target to 90 from 100. "We have a hard time imagining the NAND (flash memory)  market dynamics getting better from here, particularly given our expectation that the industry 3D NAND transition will eventually lead to a rapid expansion in bit capacity.  As such, we're moving to the sidelines for now," said analyst  James Kisner, in a report.Western Digital hit a record high Friday  after fiscal Q3 quarter earnings beat and guidance topped expectations. Results included revenue from Western Digital's purchase of SanDisk.Western Digital stock fell 1.5% to 87.70 in the stock market today.RELATED:Western Digital Hits Record High After 'Blowout' Earnings, OutlookRBC Capital hiked its price target on Comcast, the nation's biggest cable TV firm and owner of NBCUniversal, to 45 from 40. "The cable segment continues to deliver industry leading net subscriber additions on X1 (set-top box) penetration," said the RBC Capital report. "Our long-term outlook remains positive on strong subscriber trends, tailwinds at NBCU, a more benign regulatory outlook, and potential tax reform."Comcast stock closed unchanged at 39.19.Comcast on Thursday  reported double-digit gains in earnings Thursday and its shares rose to a new record high. NBCUniversal revenue jumped 14.7% to $7.87 billion, boosted by box office growth. Comcast added 42,000 video subscribers and 429,000 high-speed internet customers.RELATED:Comcast Extends Breakout As Movies, Broadband Gains Fuel Q1 EarningsJefferies hikes Chinese internet search leader Baidu's  price target to 208 from 188. Baidu last week reported Q1 revenue that came in at high-end of guidance range, with non-GAAP net income of above consensus. The Chinese internet search giant guided Q2 revenue largely in line. Baidu shares fell 4.1% on Friday to 180.23, but found support at their 50-day line.Baidu stock dipped 0.1% to 180.06.Baidu is moving into artificial intelligence for use in verticals such as auto, healthcare and financials.Morgan Stanley upgraded Autodesk to overweight from equal-weight with a price target of 115. The product-design software company in March reported fiscal Q4 results that beat expectations but Q1 guidance was light amid a major transition to cloud computing.Autodesk stock climbed 2.1% to 91.98 Monday.Monness Crespi & Hardt downgraded Shopify to neutral on valuation. Canada-based Shopify provides a cloud-based e-commerce platform that businesses use to build websites and sell goods online and across multiple sales channels, including mobile and social media. There has been speculation that Shopify a takeover target of Amazon.com (AMZN) or eBay (EBAY).Shopify rose 1.7% to 77.23.RELATED:Shopify Q4 Earnings, Q1 Revenue Guidance Beat, Shares UpIn other analyst moves, JPMorgan hiked John Deere's (DE) price point to 94 from 90 while Wedbush upgraded SunTrust Bank (STI) to buy and raised its PT to 63 from 60. Pacific Crest lowered Qualcomm's (QCOM) price target to 68 from 77 amid its legal battle with Apple (AAPL), which escalated last week. Pacific Crest raised the price target of Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO) to 53 from 51 after the flash memory controller maker surged nearly 10% on Friday following earnings. Citigroup lowered the price target of Athenahealth (ATHN)  to 128 from 143. Athenahealth shares plunged Friday on disappointing Q1 results. William Blair downgraded 8x8 (EGHT) to market perform.

XInvestors brushed off concerns of a slowdown in consumer prices and most key indexes gained on Monday. But the Dow Jones industrial average edged 0.1% lower on the back of 1-point drops or more by at least 4 of the Dow industrials' 30 components.The Nasdaq composite led the rally, rising 0.7% for the day, while the S&P 500 rose nearly 0.2%. Volume fell on both main exchanges, according to preliminary data.The Dow Jones transports slipped 0.3%.Last week, the S&P 500 large-cap benchmark rallied 1.5%, on top of a nearly 0.9% lift in the prior week. The Nasdaq had risen more than 4% over the prior two weeks, a clear signal that money continued to flow in the technology sector.In a heavy day for economic data, even bond investors didn't seem overly concerned about a surprise 0.1% dip in the March PCE prices gauge, excluding volatile energy and food prices, the first month-on-month drop since September 2001, according to Reuters. Plus, in the 12 months through March, the PCE index was up just 1.6%, vs. up 1.8% through February.The Federal Reserve has made it widely known that it wants to see inflation hitting at least 2% before taking more steps at reducing liquidity from the banking system. On Monday, meanwhile, investors sold U.S. government bonds hard; the yield on the 10-year Treasury bond inched up to 2.32%. The spread between the 2- and 10-year yields have slimmed a tad over the past 30 days.The interest-rate-sensitive Dow Jones utility average fell nearly 0.7%.Back to equities, looking at IBD's rankings of 197 industry groups, four of the top 10 groups come from the telecom and tech sectors (wireless services, semiconductor equipment, computer networking and computer data storage).Other top groups within the top 20 included the gaming group, which has vaulted from No. 80 to No. 13 over the past six weeks. Restaurants have jumped from No. 82 to No. 17 over the same time frame, while the lodging group has risen from No. 70 to No. 14.Among the four tech groups mentioned above, these names have stood out.Brooks Automation (BRKS) was up more than 5%, to 26.76, in heavy volume. The expert in automation and cryogenic systems for chipmakers and life sciences companies is extended sharply after a successful rebound off the 10-week moving average, near 16.90, in late January.Brooks also has been highlighted in the IBD Stock Spotlight.Western Digital (WDC) was down 1% to 87.97. The stock probed 52-week highs on Friday and has overall done well since it burst past an 81.77 flat-base buy point March 30. The stock is up almost 30% year to date, and harbors an A- Accumulation/Distribution Rating from IBD Stock Checkup. Watch to see if Western Digital, thriving after its acquisition of SanDisk, eases back within the 5% buy zone from the 81.77 entry, or up to 85.85. At the moment, it is too far up from the buy point to be considered for purchase.Western gets a superb 99 Composite, the maximum allowed, from IBD Stock Checkup, as well as an A for SMR (Sales + Profit Margins + Return on equity) Rating on a scale of A to E.Lam Research (LRCX) was up nearly 3% to a new high of 148.85. Shares are extended and it could be weeks before another entry develops. EPS growth in Q1 accelerated to 137%, up from gains of 20%, 0% and 43% in the prior three quarters, as sales rose 64%.Lam has been a fixture on the IBD Big Cap 20 (see the Stock Lists section on Investors.com) for several months, and currently ranks in the top 10 within the IBD 50.Other chip equipment names with outstanding Composite Ratings and excellent stock price action include ASML Holding (ASML) (broke out past an 110.24 early entry in late December, 2nd test of the 10-week moving average), and Applied Materials (AMAT), part of IBD Big Cap 20.Also in the group, Cabot Microelectronics (CCMP) is trading at new highs. But its recent pullback has produced a faulty cup base that falls short of the six-week minimum. Notice on a weekly chart how Cabot has gone two weeks down, then two weeks up into new high ground.At the same time, the 9.3% drop within the narrow consolidation was perhaps not enough to justify the V-shape-like action as an outright sell signal.Cabot faces a tough comp in fiscal Q3 earnings as profit grew 103% in the year-ago quarter that ended in June. Q3 profit this year is seen rising 5% to 83 cents a share.Among the fast-rising nontechnology groups:Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was up more than 1% to 479.29 as it made a rebound off Monday's session low. The stock has climbed sharply in recent weeks, and last week the taco-and-burrito chain marked a solid Q1 rebound in profit ($1.60 a share on an adjusted basis) and revenue ($1.07 billion, up 28%, the largest gain in 10 quarters).The strong top-line result indicated that Chipotle is winning back trust among its customers. In Q1, the Denver-based firm, with founder Steve Ells now back as sole CEO, added 57 new shops while closing 15 ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen restaurants and one Chipotle restaurant. Total restaurant count on March 31 reached 2,291.Operating margin at the restaurant level jumped to 17.7% from 6.8%, but that's still off from the 20% to 30% levels seen in prior years.Chipotle arguably broke out of a first-stage bottoming-base pattern at 434.79 at the end of March and also is extended.The Denver-based fast-casual dining pioneer sports a decent 77 RS Rating; other high-quality companies in IBD's Retail-Restaurants group with even better RS Ratings are Dave & Buster's (PLAY) at 83; Restaurant Brands (QSR) at 84; and Yum China (YUMC) at 87. Yum China, a spinoff from the KFC and Pizza Hut giant Yum Brands (YUM), has rallied 17% past a 29.45 aggressive entry within a four-month IPO base.Shares went public on Nov. 1 and ended their first trading session on the NYSE at 26.19.The Street expects earnings to grow 17% this year to $1.41 a share and 11% the next.RELATED:Stock Spotlight: The Secret Ingredient Behind These 5 Stocks' Big Moves UpHow To Invest: The Latest From IBD's Investor's CornerWhen Will Commodities Rebound? The Case For A New Bull Run In Gold

XLate-session declines whittled Wednesday's moderate gains to a weak finish.Earnings disappointments were the leading culprit, gnawing away at the week's early momentum and grinding the Dow Jones industrial average's early 0.4% gain to a 0.1% decline. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also shredded their gains, the Nasdaq ending flat and the S&P 500 down less than 0.1%.All the indexes remained firmly positive for the week.Compared to busy sessions Monday and Tuesday, Wednesday's action was comparatively quiet, with preliminary data showing trade slightly higher on the NYSE and slightly lower on the Nasdaq.At either end of the Dow industrials, United Technologies (UTX) rose nearly 2% and Procter & Gamble (PG) dropped 2%, both on quarterly results. United Tech remained in a buy range, 3% above a flat base buy point of 114.54. More than half of the Dow's stocks traded higher, with Verizon (VZ), Home Depot (HD) and Travelers (TRV) also posting gains of around 1%.Edwards Lifesciences (EW) easily led the S&P 500, pulsing more than 10% higher after reporting that strength in U.S. heart-valve replacements helped power a 32% first-quart earnings gain and a 27% rise in sales. Both numbers clobbered analyst expectations. The move hoisted shares back above the 40-week moving average as Edwards works on the right side of a six-month consolidation.Gains were more modest on the Nasdaq, led by a 3% advance by Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH). The gain put shares narrowly above a 52.60 buy point in two-month long a flat base.The low end of the Nasdaq was a different story, with Seagate Technologies (STX) gouging out a 16% loss. The maker of computer hard drives posted a 400% EPS gain, above analyst targets. But a 3% revenue advance stopped short of expectations. The loss sent shares below their 10-week moving average in heavy trade, triggering a sell signal.Hard-drive peer Western Digital (WDC) slipped 3% in strong trade. It reports earnings after the market closes on Thursday.The Leisure–Lodging group posted the strongest gain among industries as Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) spiked 9% to a record higher after turning in a powerful first-quarter performance and raising its full-year guidance. Shares ended the session 16% above a 86.82 buy point in a flat base.A heavy after hours reporting session Wednesday is scheduled to include reports from Las Vegas Sands (LVS), Citrix Systems (CTXS), Xylinx (XLNX), Amgen (AMGN), Equinix (EQIX) and others.RELATED:Trump Unveils Sweeping Tax Cut Plan; JPMorgan Says It Is 'Impossible'Las Vegas Sands Reports Late With Casino Stocks On A Hot Streak

Wireless chip maker Qualcomm (QCOM) received a stock rating downgrade on Wednesday ahead of its fiscal second-quarter earnings report after the close. Meanwhile, Broadcom (AVGO) reportedly might partner with a Japanese government-backed fund and policy bank to bid for Toshiba's semiconductor unit.Rosenblatt Securities analyst Jun Zhang lowered his rating on Qualcomm to neutral from buy with a price target of 56.Qualcomm stock was down a fraction, near 52.50, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Qualcomm's legal battle with Apple (AAPL) over patent licensing terms is likely to lead to lower chip sales for Apple's upcoming iPhone 8, he said. Qualcomm is seen losing market share to Intel (INTC) in the new handset.Apple fell 0.2% to 140.88 intraday, dropping just below a 141.12 buy point once again. Intel climbed 0.8%, regaining its 50-day line.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top-performing growth stocks includes eight chipmakers include Nvidia, Microchip Technology and Cirrus Logic."Recent supply chain work suggests that Apple will likely reduce Qualcomm modem share in the iPhone 8 from 60% to 35% in second-half 2017," Zhang said in a report. "In our view, Apple is trying to pressure Qualcomm during the litigation process."Qualcomm's market share gains with Chinese smartphone makers will not be enough to offset the revenue decline from Apple, he said."We estimate Qualcomm's (chip) shipments to Apple to be down from 75-80 million units in second-half 2016 to 45-50 million units in second-half 2017," he said. "Apple accounts for roughly 18-20% of Qualcomm's revenue, and we believe the share loss will reduce Qualcomm's revenue by $200 million per quarter in second-half 2017."Qualcomm is scheduled to report fiscal second-quarter results after the market close Wednesday.Elsewhere in the chip industry, Broadcom is considering a joint bid for Toshiba's memory chip business with Innovation Network Corp. of Japan and the Development Bank of Japan, Japan's Asahi newspaper reported.Other bidders for the prized Toshiba unit include Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry, aka Foxconn; as well as South Korea's SK Hynix and U.S.-based Western Digital (WDC), Reuters reported.Broadcom and Western Digital shares rose fractionally intraday.RELATED:Chip Stocks At 'Peak Valuations'; Nvidia Has Most Downside, Analyst SaysQualcomm: Apple Misled On Intel Chip Performance In iPhone 7

Chipmaker Broadcom (AVGO) and private equity firm Silver Lake Partners have offered about 2 trillion yen, or $17.9 billion, for the chip unit of Japanese tech giant Toshiba, the Nikkei business daily reported Friday.About 10 potential bidders are interested in buying a stake in Toshiba's Nand flash memory chip business, Reuters reported. Other companies circling the business include Western Digital (WDC), which operates a chip factory with Toshiba in Japan; and memory chip makers Micron Technology (MU) and SK Hynix.Toshiba is looking to raise at least 1 trillion yen from the sale of part or all of the business to cover write downs at its Westinghouse nuclear unit, Reuters said. It values its chip unit at about 2 trillion yen.Broadcom fell 0.5% to 218.96 on the stock market today. Broadcom is well-extended from a 179.52 buy point.In a report Friday, UBS analyst Stephen Chin said he is not surprised that Broadcom might be making a play for Toshiba's Nand business."We are not sure if a deal will happen and note the Nikkei reported there are 10 bidders," Chin said. "But if it were to, we believe the key positives for Broadcom could include: 1) successful track record integrating acquisitions, 2) delivers on (earnings per share) accretion targets, and 3) big expansion of their total addressable market."But Broadcom would face several challenges in purchasing the unit, including limited experience managing a Nand business, which is capital intensive. It also could be buying a Nand business near the peak of the chip cycle, Chin said.Chin reiterated his buy rating on Broadcom stock with a 12-month price target of 245.IBD'S TAKE: Broadcom stock has a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99 and is ranked No. 1 in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group. For more information on Broadcom, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said the possible Broadcom-Silver Lake bid is at the high end of the expected range of $13 billion to $18 billion for Toshiba's chip unit."We think it's unlikely that Broadcom intends to acquire a majority stake in Nand assets and start running fabs," Daryanani said in a report. "The likely scenario we think is: Broadcom is the minority bidder with Silver Lake to a) acquire small non-memory assets within the division (controllers, etc.) and/or b) Broadcom is doing a passive investment with Silver Lake being the primary bidder."Toshiba's Nand business would dilute Broadcom's profit margins, Daryanani said.He maintains his top pick rating on Broadcom stock with a price target of 240.RELATED:Samsung Galaxy S8 Should Help These Notable Tech Firms

More details about President Trump's tax-cut plan are expected this afternoon. Among the Dow industrials, Travelers (TRV)and United Technologies (UTX) rose 1.2% and 1.5%, respectively, in the stock market today.
