The harsh sell-off of semiconductor stocks on Thursday created a buying opportunity for investors wanting a stake in top chip companies, Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh said in a report.Semiconductor stocks fell hard Thursday as investors rotated out of the tech sector and also reacted to reports that Apple (AAPL) is cutting production of its iPhone 7 handsets, Rakesh said."The substantial pullback despite much stronger fundamentals, in our view, creates a buying opportunity," he said in a report. "Semiconductor valuations are back to Feb.-April of 2016."Rakesh recommended buying Broadcom (AVGO), Cypress Semiconductor (CY), Intel (INTC), Micron Technology (MU), Microsemi (MSCC), ON Semiconductor (ON), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Western Digital (WDC)."All have, in our view, significant growth and strong fundamentals ahead," he said.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top growth stocks includes six chip companies, such as Microsemi and Nvidia. The IBD 50 is one of many proprietary stock analysis tools for investors to consult on Investors.com.Semiconductor stocks are attractive "given the strong earnings growth, cost synergies, strong industrial, automotive, defense/aerospace, and continued synergistic M&A driven also by a better regulatory environment," Rakesh said.Rakesh's eight stock picks all dropped Thursday, but they all gained some ground on the stock market today.In his report, Rakesh also listed graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) as a buy, but said its steep valuation could give investors pause. Nvidia also edged higher Friday.Meanwhile, Needham analyst Rajvindra Gill reiterated his buy rating on audio chipmaker Cirrus Logic (CRUS) with a price target of 65. He said Cirrus was pushed down on "noise" about iPhone 7 sales."We remain bullish on CRUS as we see several vectors of growth, including further penetration of digital and ultimately ANC (active noise cancellation) headsets (beginning in Q1 2017) in the Android and accessory markets, a better iPhone 8 unit cycle, and expansion in the audio amplifier market," Gill said.Cirrus Logic rose 1.6% to 50.10 on Friday, but fell nearly 13% for the week.RELATED:Demand 'Sedate' For Apple iPhone 7, 'Robust' For iPhone 7 PlusGoPro Chip Supplier Ambarella Down On Weak Q4 Guidance

Disk drive maker Western Digital (WDC) is expected to show its strongest revenue growth in more than two years when it reports earnings after the close Wednesday, but profits keep falling.The consensus estimate is for revenue of $4.52 billion, up 35% year over year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings per share minus items of $1.01, down 33% and the seventh quarter in a row of year-over-year declines.Western Digital, along with main competitor Seagate Technology (STX), is facing slowing demand for disk drives as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.Western Digital and Seagate this month both received price-target increases from RBC Capital Markets, as conditions in the data storage market stabilize. Western Digital saw its price target raised to 65 from 60, with an outperform rating. Last week both companies received a price-target increase from Mizuho, which raised estimates on disk drive shipments.IBD'S Take: Both stocks are in IBD's data storage industry group, which has surged to No. 7 out of 197 groups from No. 81 two months ago. Seagate has an IBD Composite Rating of 75, meaning it is outperforming 75% of stocks in the past year in key metrics. Western Digital has a weaker CR of 40. For more information about trading stocks, check out IBD University.Western Digital stock rose 0.85%, to 53.52, in the stock market today. Shares broke out of a cup-with-handle base at a 54.51 buy point on Sept. 16, so remain within the buy range. Seagate stock rose a fraction to 34.52.Western Digital, which closed its acquisition of flash-chip storage provider SanDisk in May, is seeing "sustained tailwinds" across its disk-drive and chip-storage business lines, the RBC report said. It also said earnings estimates for Western Digital are positioned to keep edging up through the end of 2016.With SanDisk, Western Digital became a major competitor in both hard-disk drives and flash chip storage. SanDisk is among the largest providers of flash-chip storage, a market led by Samsung Electronics.Seagate traded down last week after posting quarterly earnings that beat the Wall Street consensus estimates, following preliminary results that Seagate posted the previous week. Seagate said it shipped a record amount of disk drive capacity, which it attributed to strong demand from cloud storage providers.Mizuho has raised its 2016 estimates for hard-disk drive shipments to 412 million from 393 million.  That would still be a 12% decline, but Mizuho earlier had estimated a 16% drop. Mizuho raised its estimate for 2017 to 385 million from 367 million.RELATED: Disk Drive Stocks Slammed Despite Seagate's Strong Guidance

Major stock indexes fell Thursday morning as Wall Street weighed another round of earnings reports, economic data and more softness in the bond market.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%, the S&P 500 0.2% and the Nasdaq composite 0.3%, losing modest opening gains.Bonds were under pressure again. The 10-year Treasury yield jumped 8 basis points to 1.87%, the highest since the end of May.Big-name earnings news powered early action on the stock market today, with the likes of ConocoPhillips (COP), Western Digital (WDC), Tesla Motors (TSLA) and ServiceNow (NOW) in play.ConocoPhillips jumped 4% after reporting better-than-forecast third-quarter results. The company raised its production outlook and cut capital spending targets.Western Digital soared nearly 7% following a healthy fiscal first-quarter beat reported late Wednesday.Tesla Motors upshifted 5% on a big third-quarter earnings beat reported after Wednesday's close. Revenue met expectations and the company topped its delivery targets. Tesla shares have been locked in a weakening consolidation since April.IBD'S TAKE: Tesla was one of several names that received positive analyst commentary Thursday.Enterprise software name ServiceNow gapped up powerfully, rising nearly 13%. The company delivered another strong quarter of growth, with earnings per share up 53% from the year-ago quarter and sales up 37% to $357.7 million.Headed into Thursday, ServiceNow was trading near a 78.87 buy point. It gapped up over the buy point Thursday. There's plenty of market precedent that shows buying a stock when it gaps up in price can be a good entry point. Just try to buy as close to the open price as possible. ServiceNow opened at 86.82. Shares were recently trading around 88.96.In economic news, first time jobless claims continued to tick lower, according to the Labor Department, dipping to 258,000 in the week ended Oct. 22. That was down from the prior week's upwardly revised 261,000 claims, but above consensus projections for a fall to 255,000 claims.Meanwhile, orders for durable goods eased 0.1% in September, the Commerce Department said. That reversed August's orders, which the department revised upward to a 0.3% increase. Minus transportation, orders rose 0.2%, topping an upwardly revised 0.1% increase in August, as well as views for another 0.1% increase.After the close, watch for earnings reports from Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Baidu (BIDU), among others.RELATED:Will Cash-Rich Google Announce New Stock Buyback With Earnings?Tesla Q3 Earnings Go Full Throttle, Topping Estimates

Stocks held an upward tilt with an hour left in Thursday's session as the major indexes look poised to make a strong weekly finish in the final days of March.The Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average rose roughly 0.3% in slightly lower volume vs. the same time on Wednesday. The market uptrend, for now, remains under pressure with five distribution days marked over the past 25 sessions for the 500.U.S. government bonds, meanwhile, edged lower and the 10-year Treasury yield rose to nearly 2.42%, according to Tradeweb, following a slight upward adjustment to the Q4 growth in U.S. GDP to 2.1% vs. a prior revised print of 1.9%. Strong consumer spending helped boost imports.The 10-year yield has swum within a relatively tight range of around 2.3% to 2.6% since December.Back to stocks, on the upside, banking, finance, farm equipment and building-related groups excelled with gains of well more than 1%. Techs also rallied. Data storage giant Western Digital (WDC) bolted more than 3% in strong turnover to 83.72, surpassing a new flat-base entry point of 81.77.Notice on an IBD daily chart that Western's relative strength line is charging into new high ground. Western Digital's up/down volume ratio is at 1.4, well above the neutral 1.0 level, and the Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B+ suggests strong accumulation by institutions.Western Digital sports an excellent 97 Composite Rating from IBD Stock Checkup on a scale of 1 to 99, and the data storage group enjoys an excellent No. 7 ranking among 197 industries ranked each day by IBD.Western had suffered a severe decline that finally ended with shares hitting bottom at 34.99 in May 2016, more than 69% below an all-time peak of 114.69. But after the Nov. 8 U.S. elections, the Irvine, Calif., company broke the long-term downtrend with a strong move past the 60 price level.Aggressive investors could have bought even earlier.On Sept. 16, Western gapped up 3.1% to 54.94 in robust turnover, 89% above its 50-day average. In so doing, the stock cleared a 54.51 entry in a seven-week cup with handle. Notice on the daily chart that the handle met the minimum length of five days. Plus, the stock had broken out after it had rallied back above the 50- and 200-day moving averages.However. it would have been totally understandable to have passed on this breakout attempt. While 54.94 was sharply higher than the recent low of 34.99, Western still down sharply off its then 52-week high of 86.39. Industry peer Seagate Technology (STX) is staging its sixth gain in seven sessions, rising more than 2% to 46.91. Shares are finding support at the 50-day line, a bullish sign.Seagate also sports enviable ratings from IBD, including a 92 RS Rating, meaning that over the past 12 months, it's outperformed 92% of all public companies. FY 2017 profit is expected to rebound 99% to $4.49 a share. Keep in mind that the data storage companies tend to show volatile earnings swings. Chipmaker Analog Devices (ADI) received two upbeat analyst reports on Tuesday, just a few days before ADI expects to close its acquisition of Linear Technology (LLTC).Pacific Crest Securities analyst Michael McConnell reiterated his overweight rating on ADI and raised his price target to 98 from 95. Meanwhile, investment bank Stifel upped its price target on ADI to 92 from 90 and maintained its buy rating.ADI shares closed down 0.5% at 83.41 on the stock market today. ADI stock broke out of a flat base with a buy point of 74.97 on Jan. 25."We remain buyers of ADI due to secular content growth in automotive, margin leverage in fiscal 2017, and the pending acquisition of LLTC, which could drive higher free cash flow, multiple expansion, and a path to $5 of EPS power by 2020," McConnell said in a report.IBD'S TAKE: Analog Devices stock has a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. It is ranked No. 1 out of 38 stocks in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group. For more information on ADI, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Norwood, Mass.-based ADI announced Monday that it has received regulatory approval from the Ministry of Commerce of China to complete its acquisition of Linear Technology. That government clearance was the final required regulatory approval, and ADI expects to complete the acquisition on Friday. The $14.8 billion cash-and-stock deal was announced last July.ADI also revised its financial guidance for its fiscal second quarter. It now expects revenue and earnings per share to be between the midpoint and high end of guidance.Analog Devices is a supplier of high-performance analog, mixed-signal and digital-signal-processors. Markets for the company's chips include communications, PCs, consumer electronics and industrial applications.Standpoint Research upgraded fabless chipmaker Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO) to buy from hold.Silicon Motion stock finished 1.6% higher at 41.36 Tuesday.Silicon Motion Technology designs Nand flash controllers for solid-state storage devices.JPMorgan added fabless chipmaker Rambus (RMBS) to its "focus list" of stocks as a "near-term long idea." It reiterated its overweight rating and price target of 14.50 on the stock.Rambus stock rose 2.3% to 13.10.On Monday, Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Rambus announced a broad patent license agreement with data storage technology firm Western Digital (WDC). The agreement covers the use of Rambus patented memory technologies — including high-speed interfaces, memory architectures, resistive memory and security technologies — in Western Digital products through 2021. The agreement includes an additional five-year extension option.RELATED:Skyworks Solutions Gets Price Target Hike On Smartphone Content Growth

Disk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) traded down Wednesday after posting quarterly earnings that beat the Wall Street consensus estimates, following preliminary results that Seagate posted last week.For its fiscal Q1 ended Sept. 30, Seagate reported revenue of $2.8 billion, up 4% year over year, reversing six straight quarters of declines. Analyst consensus was $2.78 billion. The company reported earnings per share minus items of 99 cents, 9 cents above the analyst consensus estimate, as polled by Thomson Reuters. Seagate reported preliminary results on Oct. 11, sending Seagate stock down 7.6% to 35.10.Seagate stock closed down 2.9% to 34.32 in the stock market today. Seagate rival Western Digital (WDC) dipped 0.7% to 53.60. Seagate and Western Digital are the two largest providers of disk drives.IBD'S TAKE: Seagate has an IBD Composite Rating of 62, meaning it is outperformed 62% of stocks in the past year in key metrics. Western Digital has a weaker CR of 42. For more information about trading stocks, check out the IBD University.Seagate said it shipped a record amount of disk drive capacity, which it attributed to strong demand from cloud storage providers."As the demand for hard disk drive storage continues to benefit from the shift to data driven cloud based architectures, Seagate is in a strong position to grow its businesses, improve margins and continue with its dividend and buyback capital allocation objectives," Seagate CEO Steve Luczo said in the earnings release.Seagate has recently received several price target increases as conditions in the data storage market stabilize.Seagate and Western Digital have been dealing with lower demand for disk drives as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets. Seagate said previously announced cost containment measures, and its restructuring efforts continue.Western Digital is scheduled to report quarterly earnings after the market close Oct. 26.RELATED:Western Digital, Seagate Price Targets Raised As Storage Stabilizes

He maintained a neutral rating on Seagate and raised his price target to 34 from 31.Last week, Seagate announced preliminary September-quarter data that topped Wall Street views, but the stock fell despite positive reports from analysts. Western Digital fell as well.IBD'S TAKE: Seagate has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 59, which is based on key metrics. Western Digital has a weaker CR of 47. For more information about trading stocks, check out the IBD University.Western Digital closed Monday at 53.18, down 3%. It's still within buying range of a 54.51 buy point, out of a cup-with-handle base, touched on Sept. 16, though in this volatile market investors should be cautious about new buys. Seagate stock fell 0.4% to 35.01. The stock is recovering from a deep decline.Seagate and Western Digital are dealing with lower demand for disk drives as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and portables.Despite these woes, Rakesh raised his 2016 estimate for hard-disk drive shipments to 412 million from 393 million, and raised his estimate for 2017 to 385 million from 367 million. That would be a 12% decline this year, where he had estimated a 16% drop."As we have noted, a modestly stronger PC market has been a tailwind for disk drives combined with strength in data center orders," Rakesh wrote. He also said pricing for flash-chip storage remains stable. Western Digital is a key supplier of flash-chip storage devices through its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk, which was completed in May.Seagate is slated to release September-quarter earnings after the market close Wednesday, and Western Digital on Oct. 26.Both stocks are in IBD's data storage industry group, which has surged to No. 8 out of 197 groups from No. 85 six weeks ago. Much of that climb has rested on data-backup company Carbonite (CARB), which has rallied nearly 50% from a July 22 breakout.RELATED: Western Digital, Seagate Price Targets Raised As Storage Stabilizes

Disk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) on Tuesday announced preliminary September-quarter data that topped Wall Street views, but the stock fell despite positive reports from analysts.For its fiscal Q1 ended Sept. 30, Seagate expects to report revenue of $2.8 billion, up 4% year over year, reversing six straight quarters of declines. That topped the consensus estimates of $2.75 billion. Seagate expects disk drive unit shipments of 39 million units, also topping the consensus of about 37.4 million, and gross margin of about 29%, above previous guidance of 27%.In reaction, FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi raised his price target on Seagate stock to 38 from 33 and maintained a sector perform rating. Needham analyst Richard Kugele raised his price target to 43 from 39 and raised his stock rating to strong buy from buy.Seagate stock, though, ended trading down 7.6% to 35.10 onthe stock market today. Seagate rival Western Digital (WDC) closed down 4.5% to 56.62. Seyrafi, in an email to IBD, said the drop in Seagate stock is most likely a result of investors "selling on the news." Before the drop on Tuesday, Seagate stock had nearly doubled since hitting a near four-year low of 18.42 on May 13.IBD'S TAKE: Seagate has an IBD Composite Rating of 66, meaning it is outperformed 66% of stocks in the past year in key metrics. Western Digital has a weaker CR of 55. Both Seagate and Western Digital have an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B+, indicating that institutional investors have been buying shares. For more information about trading stocks, check out the IBD University.Seagate is slated to release fiscal Q1 earnings after the market close on Oct. 19. Western Digital will report its fiscal first quarter earnings on Oct. 26, after the market close.Kugele, in upgrading Seagate to strong buy, said several positives are at work. They include PC market stabilization, significant capacity and better than expected demand for high capacity disk drives, "which we believe should help average selling prices."Last week, Seagate and Western Digital received price-target increases from RBC Capital Markets, as conditions in the data storage market stabilize.Seagate and Western Digital have been dealing with lower demand for disk drives as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets. Seagate said previously announced cost containment measures and restructuring actions continue to progress as planned."Our strong results reflect persistent growth and demand for cloud-based storage capacity and our new high capacity disk drive products are gaining traction in the marketplace," Seagate CEO Steve Luczo said in a statement.RELATED:Seagate Stock Has Best Day In Years On Guidance, Job CutsSeagate Technology Tops Estimates, But Earnings, Sales Keep Falling

A few years ago, an IBD markets writer was complaining about a stock trade. After a 42% gain in six months, he sold, but the stock rose to a more than 80% gain three months later. A colleague laughed and said, "If you're expecting us to feel sorry for you because you only made 40% on a trade, it's not going…

A byproduct of the digital economy is the ginormous amount of data that corporations and other enterprises, as well as consumers, are storing online in the internet cloud. That has been a boon for makers of data storage computers and their key components, namely hard disk drives (HDD) and solid state drives that use flash memory. Investors have responded by…

Western Digital (WDC) received applause from analysts following its quarterly earnings report late Wednesday that beat estimates on the top and bottom lines.On Tuesday, chief rival Seagate Technology (STX) also soundly beat views, and both stocks hit 15-month highs Wednesday, with Seagate up 14% and Western Digital 5%.The stocks didn't get the same boost from Western Digital's earnings, however. Western Digital stock fell 1.9% in the stock market today, though Seagate rose 2.9%.Seagate and Western Digital are the two largest providers of disk drives. They've been moving into flash chip-based storage, though, as they deal with lower product demand as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.IBD'S TAKE: Earnings season is often volatile season for stocks, sparking big gains and big declines. Keep up with the former by tracking IBD's New Highs list, which ranks the company's hitting 52-week highs by their Composite Ratings.Western Digital reported revenue of $4.9 billion, beating the consensus estimate $4.76 billion and up 48% year over year. Earnings per share minus items jumped 34% to $2.30, beating the consensus estimate of $2.13, for its fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 30.Needham analyst Richard Kugele raised his price target on Western Digital to 100 from 77 and gave it a strong buy rating."Crisp execution in a favorable market, combined with efficiency gains from the restructurings, drove a robust fiscal Q2 for Western Digital," Kugele wrote in a research note. "The company expects these trends to continue over the balance of fiscal 2017, driving our estimates higher once more."In their earnings conference call with analysts, Western Digital executives noted favorable dynamics across all end markets in disk drives and a better-than-expected PC market.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani raised his price target on Western Digital to 90 from 80, with an outperform rating."Western Digital reported impressive upside to December quarter revenue and earnings and provided a path toward higher EPS over the next several quarters," Daryanani wrote in a research note.He sees a path toward higher EPS and free cash flow, in addition to a confluence of favorable trends in both disk drives and flash-chip storage business based on Nand technology, where Western Digital is among the market leaders following its SanDisk acquisition.For the March quarter Western Digital expects revenue of about $4.55 billion, above the consensus of $4.37 billion and EPS in the range of $2 to $2.10, above Wall Street estimates of $1.69.FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi upgraded Western Digital to outperform from sector perform and raised his price target to 100, from 70.Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh raised his price target on Western Digital to 92 from 82, with a buy rating.RELATED:Western Digital Eyes Stake In Toshiba's Memory-Chip BusinessWestern Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

Stocks opened modestly higher Thursday as earnings reports continued to roll out before the opening bell.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 gained 0.2% and the Nasdaq traded up 0.3%.Big-name earnings news powered early action on the stock market today, with the likes of Ford (F), ConocoPhillips (COP), Western Digital (WDC) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) in play.NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) climbed less than 2% as Qualcomm (QCOM) jumped 4%. Qualcomm agreed to buy the Netherlands-based chip maker for $39 billion. NXP, a leading chip supplier to automotive markets, sets up Qualcomm -- primarily a cell-phone chipmaker -- to pursue autonomous driving applications.  Qualcomm is rebounding from its third test of support at the 10-week line since a breakout in July.Tesla Motors upshifted 4% on a big third-quarter earnings beat reported after Wednesday's close. Revenue met expectations and the company topped its delivery targets. Tesla shares have been locked in a weakening consolidation since April.F5 Networks (FFIV) leapt 9% at the open. The network optimization specialist's fiscal fourth-quarter revenue and earnings both topped expectations. Shares broke out past the 126.07 buy point in a two-month double-bottom base.IBD 50 stock Planet Fitness (PLNT) crunched a 3% advance at the open. The gym chain's third quarter sales and earnings easily topped views, and lifted full-year revenue guidance to above consensus estimates.  Shares ended Wednesday up 5% so far for the week, in a bid to retake support at their 10-week moving average.Ford opened 1% lower. The automaker's third-quarter earnings slipped less, revenue fell slightly more than expected by analysts. Ford shares have been in a gradual downtrend since July 2014.ConocoPhillips swung up more than 2% after reporting better-than-forecast third-quarter results. The company raised its production outlook and cut capital spending targets.Western Digital scaled up 5% following a healthy fiscal first-quarter beat reported late Wednesday.Colgate Palmolive (CL) rose 0.5% after missing analysts revenue targets.First time jobless claims continued to tick lower, according to the Labor Department, dipping to 258,000 in the week ended Oct. 22. That was down from the prior week's upwardly revised 261,000 claims, but above consensus projections for a fall to 255,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 253,000, a second straight increase.Orders for durable goods eased 0.1% in September, the Commerce Department said. That reversed August's orders, which the department revised upward to a 0.3% increase. Minus transportation, orders rose 0.2%, topping an upwardly revised 0.1% increase in August, as well as views for another 0.1% increase.September pending home sales numbers from the National Association of Realtors roll out at 10 a.m.Narrow losses were the order of business across Asia's markets on Thursday. Afternoon trade in Europe turned mixed, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.3% and Freankfurt's DAX up 0.3%.  Oil futures traded modestly higher, but West Texas Intermediate still lagged below $50 a barrel. Gold climbed a fraction, to $1,270 an ounce. The dollar rose vs. the yen, but slipped vs. the euro. The 10-year yield jumped 4 basis points to 1.83% as bonds eased.A crowded docket of companies, including Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL), Amgen (AMGN) and many others, will be out with earnings after the close.RELATED:Tesla Q3 Earnings Go Full Throttle, Topping EstimatesConoco Raises 2016 Production Outlook, Lowers Spending GuidanceWill Cash-Rich Google Announce New Stock Buyback With Earnings?

Disk drive leaders Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital (WDC) received price-target increases from RBC Capital Markets, as conditions in the data storage market stabilize.Western Digital saw its price target raised to 65 from 60, with an outperform rating.Western Digital, which closed its acquisition of chip storage provider SanDisk in May, is seeing "sustained tailwinds" across its disk-drive and chip-storage business lines, wrote RBC analyst Amit Daryanani. He said earnings estimates for Western Digital are positioned to keep inflecting higher through the end of 2016.With SanDisk, Western Digital became a major competitor in both hard disk drives and flash chip storage. SanDisk is among the largest providers of flash chip storage, a market led by Samsung Electronics.Daryanani added that disk drive pricing has been more rational on a quarter-to-quarter basis, "barring some pricing aggressiveness on the low-end PC market." He also thinks pricing on storage chips appears to be more stable than previously expected.Daryanani raised his price target on Seagate to 40 from 34, with a sector-perform rating. He said channel checks on the disk drive market "imply upside" to Q3 earnings estimates."Fundamental trends that enabled strong performance in the June quarter remained intact," he wrote.Western Digital stock rose 0.7% to 58.86 on the stock market today. Seagate stock drooped 0.4% to 38.41.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital has an IBD Composite Rating of 51, meaning it is outperformed 51% of stocks in the past year in key metrics. Seagate has a stronger Composite Rating of 67. Both Seagate and Western Digital have an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A-, indicating that institutional investors have been snapping up the stock. For more information about trading stocks, check out the IBD University.Seagate and Western Digital are dealing with lower demand for disk drives as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.RELATED:Seagate Technology Tops Estimates, But Earnings, Sales Keep FallingWestern Digital Stock Falls, As Demand Seen Just 'Modestly Improving'Seagate Stock Has Best Day In Years On Guidance, Job Cuts

Western Digital (WDC) reported quarterly earnings after the market close Wednesday that beat Wall Street estimates on the top and bottom lines.In a period that included a full quarter of SanDisk operations for the first time. Western Digital reported revenue of $4.9 billion, beating the consensus estimate $4.76 billion and up 48% year over year. It reported earnings per share minus items of $2.30, beating the consensus estimate of $2.13, for its fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 30.Western Digital stock, though, was down 2% in after-hours trading, following its earnings release and following a 5.3% rise, to 80.02, in Wednesday's regular session.Western Digital in May completed its $16 billion acquisition of flash storage provider SanDisk, creating a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital are the two largest providers of disk drives. They've been moving into flash chip-based storage, though, as they deal with lower product demand as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.Seagate reported earnings after the market close Wednesday the beat on the top and bottom line, sending its shares rising 14%. Shares of both Seagate and Western Digital hit 15-months high Wednesday.Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan in prepared remarks said the company was achieving "our planned synergy targets" with the SanDisk acquisition and also targeted cost and efficiency improvementsRELATED:Western Digital Eyes Stake In Toshiba's Memory-Chip BusinessWestern Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

Apple (AAPL), Western Digital (WDC) and Micron Technology (MU) had their price targets raised Wednesday, while Under Armour (UAA) and Mobileye (MBLY) were downgraded.Apple had its price target raised to 140 from 125 by RBC Capital Markets, which maintained an overweight weighting.Apple late Tuesday reported that in the December quarter it beat revenue and earnings estimates thanks to better-than-expected iPhone sales. Apple sold 78.3 million iPhones during its fiscal first quarter, up 5% from the same quarter last year. Analysts were looking for 77 million units.Apple stock soared 6.1% to finish the regular trading session at 128.75 on the stock market today, an 18-month high and keeping the Dow Jones Industrial Average slightly positiveRELATED:Under Armour was downgraded to market perform from outperform and had its price target cut to 20 from 39 by FBR Capital Markets, one of about a dozen downgrades.Under Armour reported fourth-quarter earnings late Tuesday that disappointed and said CFO Chip Molloy is stepping down "due to personal reasons." During the key holiday shopping season, Under Armour logged a one-cent profit decline from the prior year to 23 cents a share on 12% revenue growth to $1.3 billion, the weakest gain in eight years.Under Armour stock ended the day down 0.2% to 21.44 after crashing 26% Tuesday.Mobileye was downgraded to equal weight from overweight and had its price target cut to 44 from 48 by Morgan Stanley, due to higher R&D costs and greater competition.Some analysts say the provider of driver-assistance technology is well-positioned in the race to develop self-driving cars.  In late December, Mobileye announced it will partner with digital mapping company Here, owned by a consortium of German automakers, to develop a precise global map that can be used for hands-free driving and location services. Here poses a threat to Google Maps owner Alphabet (GOOGL).Mobileye ticked down 1 cent to 42.95, rebounding from earlier lows. Mobileye has nearly formed a handle in a cup base.Western Digital had its price target raised to 100 from 93 by Barclays, which maintained an overweight rating on the stock.The disk-drive and chip-storage provider received applause from analysts following its quarterly earnings report last week that beat estimates on the top and bottom lines.Western Digital fell 0.7% to 79.16 at the close.Micron had its price target raised to 33 from 26 by Cowen, which maintained an outperform rating.Micron saw its shares surge to an 18-month high on Dec. 22, a day after the memory-chip maker reported better-than-expected fiscal Q1 earnings and guided much higher than views for the current quarterMicron stock ended the trading day at 24.75, up 2.7%.

Disk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) late Tuesday reported quarterly earnings that easily topped Wall Street views on the bottom, with the top line also coming in better than expected. Seagate also gave bullish revenue guidance.Seagate reported revenue of $2.9 billion. That's down 3% from the year-earlier quarter, but that's is smallest percentage decline in nearly two years and it beat the consensus estimate of $2.82 billion. It reported earnings per share minus items of $1.38, up 68% and well above the consensus of $1.08, for its fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 30.On the post-earnings call, Seagate said it sees current Q3 revenue of about $2.7 billion vs. views for around $2.6 billion. It also expects full-year EPS of "at least $4.50" vs. Wall Street's forecast for $3.77.Seagate stock was up 14% to 42.65 in after-hours trading, which would be a 15-month high Shares rose 2.9% to 37.44 on the stock market today.Rival disk drive maker Western Digital (WDC) rose 5.3% to 80.01 in late trading. Western Digital reports fiscal second-quarter earnings after the close Wednesday, with expectations of double-digit growth on the top and bottom lines.Seagate and Western Digital, as the two largest providers of disk drives, have for several years been dealing with lower product demand as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.Both companies have been expanding into chip-based storage, with Western Digital being the most aggressive. Western Digital in May completed its $16 billion acquisition of flash storage provider SanDisk, creating a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.Seagate approved a quarterly cash dividend of 63 cents per share, which will be payable on April 5, to shareholders of record as of the close of business on March 22.RELATED:Western Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

Seagate Technology (STX) received a flood of price-target hikes from investment banks following its quarterly earnings and guidance beat late Tuesday, sending shares soaring Wednesday.The data storage company received at least 14 price-target hikes from analysts, with the new targets ranging from 40 to 55.Seagate stock was up 20% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 45, hitting a 15-month high and extending past a buy point of 41.55. Shares essentially are clearing a deep bottoming base pattern.Seagate and Western Digital (WDC) are the two largest providers of disk drives. They's been moving into flash chip-based storage, though, as they deal with lower product demand as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.Western Digital stock also hit a 15-month high, up 6% near 80.50 midday Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: As the Dow reached the elusive 20,000 mark, a range of stocks were at or near new highs. To read which ones are worth watching, check out IBD's stock market analysis.Western Digital in May completed its $16 billion acquisition of flash storage provider SanDisk, creating a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.Western Digital reports quarterly earnings after the market close Wednesday. It will include a full quarter of SanDisk operations for the first time. Western Digital is expected to report revenue of $4.76 billion. That would be 44% above the same quarter last year. The consensus on earnings per share minus items is $2.13, up 33%.Both companies are benefiting from restructurings, acquisitions, an improved market for disk drives and the anticipation of a memory-chip shortage this year, which should drive prices higher.Other beneficiaries in the chip storage field include Micron Technology (MU). Micron stock touched a 19-month high early Wednesday, and was up 2%, near 23.30. Micron saw its shares surge to an 18-month high on Dec. 22, a day after the memory chipmaker reported better-than-expected fiscal first-quarter earnings and guided much higher than views for the current quarter.Seagate late Tuesday reported quarterly earnings that easily topped Wall Street views on the bottom, with the top line also coming in better than expected. Seagate also gave bullish revenue guidance.On its earnings conference call with analysts, Seagate said it sees current-quarter (fiscal Q3) revenue of about $2.7 billion vs. views for around $2.6 billion. It also expects full-year EPS of "at least $4.50" vs. Wall Street's forecast for $3.77.Needham analyst Richard Kugele maintained a strong buy rating on Seagate stock, raising his price target to 55 from 47. Kugele said Seagate's restructuring "is clearly working," with disk drive storage demand seen as stable to improving."We see significant upside to the stock in 2017," he wrote.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani raised his price target to 45 form 40, maintaining a sector perform rating.RELATED:Western Digital Eyes Stake In Toshiba's Memory-Chip BusinessWestern Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

After a weekslong courtship, Qualcomm (QCOM) reportedly is set to marry NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).San Diego-based Qualcomm has reached an agreement to acquire Dutch chipmaker NXP for about $110 a share in cash, CNBC reporter David Faber said Friday. Other details are still being negotiated, he said. The deal would value NXP at roughly $37 billion. Reuters also reported that a deal has been reached.By the closing bell Friday, Qualcomm shares added 0.9% to 67.93 on the stock market today. NXP stock, however, dropped 2.7% to 101.71.IBD'S TAKE: The semiconductor sector is one of the hottest areas of the stock market now. The IBD 50 list of superior stocks includes eight chip industry stocks, but Qualcomm and NXP are not among them. Check out the article titled "Semiconductor Sector Still Offers Plenty Of Leadership."

An acquisition of NXP would help Qualcomm diversify beyond mobile-phone chips. The deal would give Qualcomm exposure to the automotive, industrial and Internet of Things markets.Qualcomm was among the chipmakers hurt by Samsung's recent decision to cancel its fire-prone Galaxy Note 7 smartphone. Qualcomm gets nearly 3% of its revenue from Samsung, Pacific Crest Securities estimates.Purchasing NXP would allow Qualcomm to become an end-to-end chip supplier to the automotive market.The deal would create the second-largest chip company by revenue, after Intel (INTC).News of the possible Qualcomm-NXP tie-up was first reported on Sept. 29, sending NXP shares up 17% on the day.Spokespeople for NXP and Qualcomm on Friday said it is company policy to not comment on rumors or speculation.Qualcomm's two largest acquisitions to date were its $2.4 billion purchase of CSR in 2015 and $3.1 billion purchase of Atheros Communications in 2011.Headquartered in the Netherlands, NXP makes high-performance mixed-signal processors for communications, security, automotive and industrial applications. Among its biggest customers are Apple (AAPL), Bosch, Ericsson (ERIC), Huawei, Hyundai, Nokia (NOK) and Samsung.If the Qualcomm-NXP merger occurs, it would be part of a wave of consolidation occurring in the chip sector.In May, disk drive maker Western Digital (WDC) completed its $19 billion acquisition of flash chip company SanDisk. On Feb. 1, the biggest chip merger ever -- biggest merger of two tech companies ever -- was completed between Avago and Broadcom (AVGO), with the $37 billion combination taking the Broadcom name but keeping Avago's AVGO stock ticker. And in December, NXP completed its own huge deal, acquiring Freescale Semiconductor in a transaction valued near $12 billion.Qualcomm and NXP are members of IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group, which currently ranks No. 10 out of 197 groups.RELATED:Qualcomm Gathers Strength Amid Note 7 Demise, Possible NXP Deal

Chipmaker Intel (INTC) got an assist from improved personal computer sales in the third quarter, but its high-margin data center chip business disappointed.Intel stock fell 5.9% to 35.51 on the stock market today, after the No. 1 chipmaker posted Q3 results late Tuesday.At least seven Wall Street analysts cut their price targets on Intel stock on the news.IBD'S TAKE: Intel stock cleared a buy point at 36.03 last month, but threatened to close below the pivot on Wednesday. Shares fell below their 50-day moving average line on Wednesday for the first time since late June. For more information on Intel stock, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Intel lowered its sales growth target for its data center chip unit to high single digits for the full year. That's down from projections for midteens growth at the start of the year.Intel's data center group accounts for about half the company's operating profit.For Q3, Intel reported $4.5 billion in data center chip business, missing Wall Street views for $4.6 billion. Sales in the unit were up 10% year over year.Intel's data center group remains the company's "crown jewel growth franchise, but near-term growth continues to disappoint," Canaccord Genuity analyst Matthew Ramsay said in a research report.Intel's largest unit, its client computing group, saw sales rise 5% year over year to $8.9 billion in Q3. Total sales rose 9% to $15.78 billion. Intel earned 80 cents a share excluding items in Q3, up 21% and topping Wall Street's target of 73 cents.But for Q4, Intel expects sales of $15.7 billion, vs. analyst expectations for $15.86 billion.Intel also forecast a decline in gross profit margin to 63% on a non-GAAP basis in Q4, from 64.8% in Q3. Its gross margin guidance implies non-GAAP earnings per share of 71 cents in Q4, vs. consensus views for 77 cents, UBS analyst Stephen Chin said in a report."The bulls will point to (data center group) reaccelerating and PCs stabilizing," RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani said in a report Wednesday. "However, bears will likely point to further PC market declines, a deteriorating core enterprise business in (the data center group) and a slowing of cloud/networking-centric DCG spend."Intel's Q3 report is likely to weigh on companies with meaningful exposure to the enterprise and PC segments, including Cisco Systems (CSCO), Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE), Marvell Technology (MRVL), Micron Technology (MU), Super Micro Computer (SMCI), Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital (WDC), Pacific Crest Securities said Tuesday.All of the above stocks fell Wednesday except for HPE, which got positive reviews for its analyst day Tuesday, and Super Micro. Seagate, which reported earnings Wednesday, fell 2.9%.RELATED:Seagate Earnings Beat On Strong Cloud Storage Demand

Mobile chip company Qualcomm (QCOM) had its price target raised, as did disk drive makers Seagate Technology (STX) and Western Digital (WDC), while oilfield services provider Halliburton (HAL) was raised to a buy.RBC Capital Markets raised his price target on Qualcomm to 70 from 59 and maintained an outperform rating. Qualcomm is reportedly in talks to acquire NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) in a bid that values NXP at about $30 billion."While the NXP transaction is certainly much larger vs. what investors had contemplated," wrote RBC analyst Amit Daryanani in a research note, "we think it offers Qualcomm with several unique assets to further enable diversity away from their 90% mobility exposure."Qualcomm shares fell 2% to close at 67.11 on the stock market today.Seagate Technology and Western Digital received price target increases at RBC Capital Markets.Western Digital had its price target raised to 65 from 60, with an outperform rating.Western Digital, which closed its acquisition of SanDisk in May, is seeing "sustained tailwinds" across and business lines, wrote RBC analyst Daryanani. He said earnings estimates for Western Digital are positioned to keep inflecting higher through the end of 2016.Western Digital stock closed up 0.7% at 58.86.Daryanani raised his price target on Seagate to 40 from 34, with a sector perform rating. He said channel checks on the disk drive market "imply upside" to Q3 earnings estimates."Fundamental trends that enabled strong performance in the June quarter remained intact," he wrote.Shares fell 0.4% to 38.41.RBC lowered its price target on Gilead Sciences (GILD) to 95 from 105. RBC analyst Michael Yee wrote that the price target is reasonable and in line with comparable low-growth large-cap drug companies but also reflects the lack of visibility on the long-term trajectory of its hepatitis C vaccine franchise, which is facing "increasing competitive uncertainties."Shares fell 1.4% to 78.03, close to two-year lows set last month.Societe Generale upgraded Halliburton to a buy from hold. A bounce in oil prices and rising confidence in forecasts that the industry's supply glut will end heading into 2017 are luring speculative dollars back into U.S. exploration and oilfield services stocks. Analysts project a broad recovery among domestic energy producers in 2017.Shares initially rallied but finished essentially flat at 44.90.

Stocks backed out of mixed trade into increasing losses early Friday, as weak economic news and earnings reports placed pressure on the morning's trade.The Dow and the S&P 500 dropped 0.5% apiece, while the Nasdaq slipped 0.6%. Small caps fell at a slightly faster pace, with the Russell 2000 showing a 0.8% decline.  Volume rose in the stock market today, gaining 3% on the NYSE and 7% on the Nasdaq, vs. trade at the same time Thursday.Economic news opened with below-forecast growth in personal spending and prices for March, although personal income outpaced projections. Midwest manufacturing slowed, with Kingsbury International reporting its April Chicago purchasing managers index at 50.4 for the month, down from 53.6 in March and far weaker than the 53.4 tally expected by analysts.Consumer views also dimmed in April, according to the University of Michigan, which put its Consumer Sentiment Index at 89 for the month — below March's 89.7 and disappointing forecasts for an increase to 90.4.More than 25 of the 30 Dow stocks moved lower at the open. Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Intel (INTC) were the only two to drop more than 1%. Exxon Mobil (XOM) led, rising 1% after reporting mixed first quarter results.Tech stocks soaring after quarterly reports were the market's focal point in early trade: Amazon.com (AMZN) soared 10%, Expedia (EXPE) leapt 9% and LinkedIn (LNKD) advanced 6%.Get detailed chart analysis on Amazon.com by subscribing to IBD's Leaderboard feature. Oil and energy stocks were pounding out strong gains, holding many of the top slots in the S&P 500, as oil prices advanced almost 1% ahead of the weekly rig count report from Baker Hughes (BHI), due out at 1 p.m.ET.But earnings news also energized broader segments of the market.Housewares leader Newell Brands (NWL) gapped up to a 7% gain after its first quarter revenue and earnings topped projections, and management lifted its Q2 guidance above consensus views. The heavy volume gain hoisted shares above a 45.67 buy point in a first stage cup-with-handle base.Among pharmaceutical stocks, Ireland's Shire (SHPG) popped 4% in powerful volume after a a strong Q1 report. The stock is working on its sixth straight weekly advance. Gilead Sciences (GILD) dived 5% as both its earnings and revenue missed first quarter expectations.  The loss put shares down nearly 10% for the week, killing an attempt to build the right side of a six-month consolidation.Medical waste collection specialist Stericycle (SRCL) crumbled to a 20% loss. As an analyst downgrade followed Thursday's Q1 earnings miss. The loss set the stock back to 2013 levels.Hard drive makers Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technologies (STX) posted deep declines after reporting their fiscal Q3 results.Seagate unraveled 15% as earnings fell far short of consensus projections and revenue just met previously lowered guidance. S&P Global maintained its hold rating on the stock and lowered its price target to 29, from 31.Western dropped 10% as both earnings and revenue stopped short of analyst projections. Robert W. Baird downgraded the stock to neutral from outperform and lowered its price target to 50, from 55.Among IBD 50 stocks, nearly all of the list moved lower at the start of trade.  Stamps.com (STMP) was among the few exceptions, rising 2% in strong trade, taking back a small piece of Thursday's 12% tumble.On the downside, Ellie Mae (ELLI) pared an initial 12% dive to 8% ,after what appeared to be a solid Q1 report. Earnings and revenue topped analyst consensus views. Management gave an upbeat view of company performance and outlook, and raised guidance above projections.  Stephens & Co. downgraded the stock to equal weight, from overweight, following the report. The loss put Ellie's shares below their 50-day moving average in very heavy trade.

Stocks tumbled in and out of mixed trade Thursday morning as earning reports, economic news and overseas factors all had a say in early action.The Nasdaq held up a 0.2% gain, buoyed primarily by Facebook (FB). The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.4% and the S&P 500 dipped 0.2%.Volume rose mildly, up 1% on the NYSE and 8% higher on the Nasdaq, vs. action at the same time Wednesday.The stock market today felt early pressure from overseas markets, which traded generally lower after the Bank of Japan held its monetary policy unchanged and sent the yen soaring and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 to a 3.6% loss Thursday. Economic news increased that weight, after the Labor Department estimated Q1 GDP growth at 0.5%, sharply below Q4 growth and below the consensus view for 0.7%.Nearly all Dow stocks declined at the open. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) led the few advancing issues, up 0.9%. DuPont (DD) shouldered the heaviest loss, down more than 2%, possibly affected by investor response to Q1 results from its pending merger mate Dow Chemical (DOW). Dow's results topped expectations, but the economic outlook appeared wobbly. Dow shares slipped 2%.Facebook easily led the Nasdaq 100 with a 10% advance. Facebook's Q1 earnings report late Wednesday triggered a handful of analyst price target increases Thursday morning. The gain sent shares 2% past a 117.09 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.At the weak end of the Nasdaq 100, chipmaker Xilinx (XLNX) tanked 10%. The company reported late Wednesday its Q1 earnings and revenue narrowly topped consensus views. Management guided Q2 EPS in line with views, but guidance for flat revenue disappointed expectations.Acquisitions news powered a healthy piece of early trade. St. Jude Medical (STJ) opened 24% higher after fellow heart-device maker Abbot Labs (ABT) agreed to buy the company in a $25 billion deal. Abbott's shares fell more than 8%.Facebook's technical and fundamental vital signs are avaible using IBD's Stock Checkup featureBiomed Medivation (MDVN) scribed an early 9% advance, ignited by a $9.3 takeover proposal from France's Sanofi (SNY). Sanofi shares shed 2%.Chicago-based drugmaker Abbvie (ABBV) slumped almost 5% after announcing plans to acquire privately held cancer treatment biomed Stemcentrix in a deal valued at $5.8 billion.Outside of the medical territories, Comcast (CMCSA) sealed its deal to ingest Dreamworks Animations (DWA) for around $3.8 billion. Dreamworks traded flat on Thursday, after spiking 19% on the news in Wednesday's session. Comcast traded a fraction lower Thursday, and was down 0.3% on the week.Haynesbrands (HBI) jockeyed 9% higher after announcing it would pay $835 million to acquire leading Australian undergarment maker Pacific Brands.Companies scheduled to report after today's close include Amazon.com (AMZN), Baidu (BIDU), Netsuite (N), LinkedIn (LKND) and Western Digital (WDC), among many others.

Stocks stuck to their thin, early gains Thursday as investors appeared set to hold fire ahead of Friday's March payrolls report.The Nasdaq led, up 0.2%. The Dow and S&P 500 held to fractional gains. Volume was weak, down 17% on the NYSE and 29% lower on the Nasdaq, compared with trade at the same time Wednesday.The stock market today wraps up its March and first quarter trading periods. While the Nasdaq is down nearly 3% and the S&P 500 up just over 1% for the quarter, the two indexes are both tracking toward gains of 6.9% for March - their first monthly gains since November.Early jobs data were mixed, with Challenger, Gray & Christmas reporting a nice decline in layoffs in its March Job Cuts Report. The Labor Department countered with a much heftier-than-expected rise in weekly unemployment claims.Midwest manufacturing saw a nice jump in March, lifting Kingsbury International's Chicago Purchasing Managers Index to 53.6 for the month, up from February's 47.6 reading and easily outdistancing forecasts for a rise to 50.3.IBM (IBM) led the Dow with a 1.3% advance. Boeing (BA) lagged the group with a 1.3% loss.On the Nasdaq 100, Western Digital (WDC) popped 2% after restructuring more than $5 billion of its debt out through 2023-24.Biomed Medivation (MDVN) was a standout, spiking 17% after news reports said the San Francisco-based company had enlisted JPMorgan to help it mull takeover strategies.Refiner Tesoro (TSO) dropped 3% in heavy trade, one of the worst declines among S&P 500 stocks. Shares have slipped in three prior sessions, putting the stock down 9% this week and tracking toward what would be its first decline in seven weeks.Among IBD 50 stocks, Scripps Networks (SNI) bumped up 2% after reporting that all six of its networks, including the Travel and Cooking Channel's, scored year-over-year audience gains in the first quarter. The stock has climbed 39% off an October low.   It remains deep in a 20-month consolidation.Chip developer MaxLinear (MXL) added 1.4%. It has clawed back to 11% above a 16.29 buy point, after diving below that pivot to test support at its 10-week moving average.China's New Oriental Education & Technology (EDU) dipped 2% in quiet volume. It is still 6% past a 33.01 buy point, trading tightly, just below a March 18 high.

Summit Research initiated coverage of Western Digital (WDC) with a buy rating, saying that the company's market position improved following its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk (SNDK) this month.Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan set a price target on Western Digital of 74. Western Digital stock was near 46, down a fraction, in afternoon trading in the stock market today and just above its 50-day moving average.Western Digital is the largest supplier of disk drives, followed closely by Seagate Technology (STX). Western Digital holds a 44% share of the disk drive market, with Seagate at 40%.Western Digital shareholders approved the deal to acquire SanDisk early this month, creating a company that is a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage. SanDisk is a leading provider of chips used for data storage in a wide variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets and PCs. The acquisition is expected to double Western Digital’s addressable market from to $75 billion from $37 billion.Sundararajan, in a research report, said that SanDisk, which has a strong retail business, will be able to move up the ladder in the enterprise market, where Western Digital is strongest. Western Digital, meanwhile, gets the ability to offer chip-based storage in areas where its disk drive technology is losing ground. The combined company will have annual revenue of nearly $20 billion, vs. $13.7 billion for Seagate.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The data storage market will come into focus as Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) get set to report quarterly earnings, with both stocks on a roll Tuesday.Western Digital, Seagate and chipmaker Micron Technology (MU) are all expected to benefit if a shortage of DRAM and flash-based memory chips emerges, as some expect.Western Digital and Seagate will also benefit if disk drive supplies tighten as the PC and computer server market stabilizes after a multiyear slowdown.Western Digital stock was up 4.2% to 75.73 in afternoon trading in the stock market today, hitting a 15-month high. Seagate stock also up 3.2% to 37.54, but it's still trading below its 50-day moving average.Micron stock leapt 4.7% to 22.92 intraday. Micron saw its shares surge to an 18-month high on Dec. 22, a day after the memory chipmaker reported better-than-expected fiscal first-quarter earnings and guided much higher than views for the current quarter.Samsung Electronics reported strong earnings overnight, as the Korean tech giant reported strong memory chip gains.IBD'S TAKE: Western Digital has been performing better than Seagate. Western Digital has an IBD Composite Rating of 75, meaning it has outperformed 75% of stock in the past year in a variety of measurements. Seagate has a CR of 63.On the storage earnings front, Seagate is up first, reporting after the close Tuesday. Western Digital follows on Wednesday after the close.Seagate and Western Digital, as the two largest providers of disk drives, have for several years been dealing with lower product demand as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.Both companies have been expanding into chip-based storage, with Western Digital being the most aggressive. Western Digital in May completed its $16 billion acquisition of flash storage provider SanDisk, creating a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.The consensus estimate is for Seagate to report revenue of $2.82 billion, down 5% year over year and the sixth straight quarter of year-over-year declines. The consensus on earnings per share minus items is $1.08, up 32%, for its fiscal second quarter.Western Digital's results will include a full quarter of SanDisk operations for the first time. Western Digital is expected to report revenue of $4.76 billion. That would be 44% above the same quarter last year.The consensus on earnings per share minus items is $2.13, up 33%.SanDisk is a leading provider of chips used for data storage in a wide variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets and PCs. With SanDisk, Western Digital sees its total addressable market at $72 billion.Western Digital is considering buying a stake in the flash-memory business of Toshiba, which needs the funds to cover a looming multibillion-dollar write-down due to an accounting scandal. Western Digital and Toshiba jointly operate a flash-memory plant in Japan.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani, has an outperform rating and 80 price target on Western Digital stock.RELATED:Western Digital President: Tackling 'Third Platform' Of Data StorageWestern Digital Displays 'Operational And Financial Excellence'

The Dow Jones industrial average hit 20,000 as the major averages rallied to fresh record highs on President Trump's early policy moves. Earnings reports generally were positive, but Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL), Starbucks (SBUX) were among those with disappointing results. M&A deals, buzz and rejections were rife.The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3% for the week, topping 20,000 for the first time. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 also hit record highs, up 1.9% and 1%, respectively, amid a slew of earnings, including Intel (INTC), Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), Alibaba (BABA) and Boeing (BA). President Trump authorized a border wall and two key oil pipelines, lifting a wide variety of construction and materials related firms such as Caterpillar (CAT) and Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), but not steel makers. Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB) broke out, joining other FANG+ stocks. The 10-year Treasury yield rose, lifting bank stocks.Google parent Alphabet said Q4 earnings per share minus items rose 8% to $9.36, below views for $9.64. Total revenue rose 22% to $26.1 billion, topping forecasts for 25.26 billion. Revenue growth slowed from 28% in the prior-year period. The internet search and advertising giant faced tough comparisons with the prior-year quarter, when it launched new advertising products. Capital spending soared 46% to $3.1 billion, which much of that related to its cloud computing efforts. Marketing costs for Google's new Pixel smartphones also were heavy.Alphabet shares fell 1.4% on Friday after hitting record highs earlier in the week.RELATED:Alphabet Q4 EPS Misses ExpectationsFiscal Q2 earnings rose 9% to 83 cents a share while revenue climbed 2% to $26.07 billion, beating views for 79 cents and $25.30 billion. Credit a booming cloud computing business, including Azure. Microsoft guided Q3 revenue forecasts higher. Microsoft shares rose nearly 5% for the week, hitting record highs.RELATED:Microsoft Beats Q2 Targets On Cloud Computing StrengthThe chipmaker's EPS rose 4%, topping views, while its 10% sales growth was the best in four years. Intel also gave bullish guidance. Intel shares rose 1.1% Friday after breaking out of a base earlier in the week ahead of earnings. Texas Instruments (TXN) also reported strong earnings, while Samsung Electronics credit memory chip gains for its overall Q4 profit revival. Microsemi (MSCC) also had good results, along with chip gear makers Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor (KLAC). But mobile chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM), facing FTC charges and Apple lawsuits over its licensing practices, reported mixed results.RELATED:Intel Q4 Earnings, Sales Top Expectations, Revenue Guidance Also BeatsThe economy expanded at a 1.9% annual rate in the fourth quarter, below views for 2.2% and not much more than half of Q3's 3.5% gain. For 2016, U.S. GDP grew just 1.6%, the 11th straight year below 3%. Meanwhile, durable goods orders unexpectedly fell for a second straight month in December. New-home sales tumbled to a 10-month low, though several homebuilders remained bullish after reporting solid earnings.Starbucks (SBUX) reported its weakest earnings growth in five years, though that met views. Sales missed forecasts with customer traffic down 2%. The coffee shop giant, which also cut its revenue outlook, said its mobile order and pay was so popular that it created bottlenecks at order pick up, turning off some patrons. Starbucks shares fell 4% on Friday. Meanwhile, McDonald's (MCD) topped EPS and sales targets but U.S. comps fell as investors questioned if the momentum from the all-day breakfast menu has run out. McDonald's tested key support levels initially but closed the week up 0.5%.RELATED:Too Much Of A Good Thing? This Weighed On Starbucks' U.S. PerformanceMcDonald's Stock Tests Key Support Amid Turnaround DoubtsA federal judge ruled that the $37 billion Aetna (AET)-Humana (HUM) merger would violate antitrust laws by unduly reducing competition among health insurers. Aetna, which owes Humana a $1 billion breakup fee, may appeal. The deal also throws into doubt the proposed $48 billion Anthem (ANTM)-Cigna (CI) merger deal, which the Justice Department also opposes.RELATED:Aetna's $37 Billion Deal For Humana Blocked By Federal JudgeSeveral steel makers sold off during the week, breaking below their 50-day lines as earnings reports failed to support stocks after a postelection run, even as President Trump touted various infrastructure plans and signaled more protectionism. AK Steel (AKS) topped views Tuesday, but shares reversed sharply lower on a weak pricing outlook. Steel Dynamics (STLD), which had decent earnings late Tuesday, tumbled Wednesday. Larger peers U.S. Steel (X) and Nucor (NUE), which both report on Jan. 31, also sold off. But many of the steel makers rebounded Thursday and Friday. On the upside, specialty steel firm Allegheny Steel (ATI) delivered stellar earnings Tuesday, sending shares up 31% that day.RELATED:Steel Stocks Break Key Support Even As Trump Rally ResumesAK, Allegheny Earnings Top, Steel Dynamics Meets; Steel Stocks Bend Both WaysBoeing (BA) emphasized the importance of trade with China for aerospace industry jobs in the U.S. but is bullish about President Trump's tax reforms and regulations. Boeing reported Q4 EPS and revenue above analyst views. Its guidance was cautious, but its 787 Dreamliner is now cash flow positive,which bodes well for future stock buybacks and dividend increases. Boeing shares broke out of a base, hitting record highs. Lockheed Martin (LMT) reported Q4 earnings and revenue above analyst views with aeronautics revenue, which includes F-35 sales, soaring 23% to $5.41 billion. It expects a surge in F-35 deliveries this year. But Lockheed gave weak guidance amid continued concerns about F-35 costs, sending shares lower.Northrop Grumman (NOC) beat on Q4 views while Raytheon (RTN) fell short. Like Boeing and Lockheed, they gave weak guidance.General Dynamics (GD) reported strong earnings and gave bullish long-term guidance.RELATED:Boeing Backs U.S.-China Trade As Trump Protectionism LoomsLockheed Sees 2017 Jump In F-35s But Guides Profit Low Amid Cost FlapNorthrop, Raytheon Join Lockheed With Weak Views But New Budget LoomsVerizon Communications (VZ) stock sold off 6% on disappointing 2017 guidance, which also sparked speculation over possible mergers with cable firm Charter (CHTR), as well as Dish Network (DISH) and Walt Disney (DIS). Verizon reported a mixed Q4, with revenue falling 5.4% but beating estimates while EPS was light. Wireless margins missed.Management pushed back its goal of returning to wireless service growth to 2018. The close of Verizon's purchase of Yahoo (YHOO) will be delayed until Q2 as regulators look into its data breaches.AT&T (T) reported in-line Q4 EPS, with revenue and EBITDA slightly below consensus. AT&T again lost wireless postpaid phone subscribers. AT&T remained upbeat on regulatory approval of its Time Warner (TWX) acquisition.Comcast (CMCSA) Q4 earnings topped views amid solid subscriber gains. The cable TV firm plans to buy back $5 billion in shares in 2017, hiked its dividend and announced a 2-for-1 stock split. Comcast plans to launch its wireless service buy midyear. Comcast rose 3% for the week to new highs.RELATED:Verizon Stock Falls; EPS, Revenue Outlook More Of The SameVerizon, Charter Talks Heating Up? Malone Vision KeyComcast Tops On Earnings, Hikes Dividend, Offers Wireless HintsWill AT&T Cross-Selling Success Spur Comcast Wireless Buy?Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) agreed to pay $30 billion for Swiss biotech Actelion. J&J reported weak sales and guidance earlier in the week. Celgene (CELG) missed on sales even after preannouncing Q4 results. Biogen (BIIB) stock popped despite light sales on "better-than-feared" 2017 guidance following its hemophilia unit spinoff. Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) missed on earnings and gave weak EPS guidance amid weaker lung cancer drug prospects.RELATED:Johnson & Johnson Will Buy Actelion For $30 BillionBristol-Myers Topples On 2017 Guidance Cut Amid Merck I-O CompetitionCelgene Aims To Hurdle Revlimid Patent LossDisk drive makers Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) both reported quarterly results that topped views. Along with bullish guidance, the results suggested a multiyear slump disk-drive shipments may have bottomed. Both companies are also investing heavily in flash-based chip storage, following market needs. Seagate shares shot up 22% and Western Digital 9%, both setting 15-month bests.RELATED:Western Digital Gets Positive Reviews On 'Crisp Execution'Alibaba (BABA) revenue rose 54% in local currency to $7.67 billion, with EPS rising 30% to $1.30 above views. Revenue from its cloud computing unit rose 115% to $254 million. Shares of the e-commerce giant rose more than 6% for the week, as Alibaba builds the right side of a base.RELATED:Alibaba Crushes Earnings Estimates, Raises GuidanceFord (F) topped fourth-quarter results expectations, and sees a sluggish 2017. CEO Mark Fields said the automaker has the right amount of U.S. plants it needs, despite President Trump's call days earlier for the Big 3 to build more U.S. factories. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), meanwhile, said net income doubled, helped by cost savings, while revenue ticked up 1% to $31.4 billion.Ford CEO Says U.S. Plants 'Appropriate'; Q4 Profit Meets, Sales TopCisco Systems (CSCO) late Tuesday announced it would buy AppDynamics for $3.7 billion, a day before the latter was expected to price an IPO with a top target valuation of $1.7 billion. AppDynamics, which was going to be the year's first "tech unicorn" to go public, provides cloud-based software that measures and analyzes the performance of business critical applications.Cisco Systems Nabs AppDynamics For $3.7 Billion, Just Before IPO

Price targets for Alibaba (BABA) and Seagate Technology (STX) were raised Wednesday after reporting strong quarterly results Tuesday while Lockheed Martin's (LMT) PT was lowered and Verizon Communications (VZ) was downgraded.Wedbush raised Alibaba's price target to 100 from 90 and kept a neutral rating on the stock.On Tuesday China's e-commerce leader reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings and revenue and raised its 2017 fiscal year revenue guidance from 48% to 53% year-over-year growth.Alibaba shares climbed 2.6% to 104.06 on the stock market today after rising 3.1% on Tuesday.Mizuho raised its price target on Seagate Technology to 40 from 24 after the disk drive maker reported Q2 earnings and revenue above views and issued bullish revenue guidance.

When Western Digital (WDC) closed its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk in May, the leading provider of disk drives greatly expanded in the business of flash-based chip-storage products widely used in mobile devices.Western Digital made the acquisition to address the dramatic growth in data creation and the evolution of data storage.SanDisk has long been among the leaders in flash-based chip storage, the kind used in smartphones and tablet computers. With SanDisk, Western Digital sees its total addressable market at $72 billion.Already the No. 1 provider of disk drives, just ahead of archrival Seagate Technology (STX), Western Digital now is also a formidable player in chip-based flash storage. Western Digital and Seagate for several years have been dealing with lower demand for disk drives as consumers shift from desktop PCs to smartphones and tablets.The move helped Western Digital's stock, which is up 17% in 2016 and trading well above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages, key support lines. Western Digital stock fell a fraction to 70.17 in the stock market today.The data storage market is evolving to meet the growing demands of cloud computing, mobile computing, the Internet of Things and other forms of computing, Mike Cordano, Western Digital's president and chief operating officer, recently told IBD in a Q&A about the road ahead in 2017.IBD: With the SanDisk acquisition done, what kind of 2017 do you expect from Western Digital?Cordano: For one, we hope to reach our full stride as an integrated company — the new Western Digital, combining all the SanDisk assets. We're through the first big wave of this integration. We're in a position to deploy an integrated product roadmap across various markets that are changing dramatically.IBD'S TAKE: There are plenty of places on Investors.com to research and find top stocks, but when you're looking to get a broader idea on top tech stocks, IBD's Tech Leaders feature is worth reviewing. You can, for example, find out about four tech earnings leaders.What we see happening is an acceleration of new computing architectures. Some people call it a third platform. It's the advent of cloud mobility and other things like artificial intelligence and machine learning. For us it's really about continuing to provide the technology and storage-product building blocks. We've got a very clear focus on that across the breadth of the company. Having SanDisk and its nonvolatile memory, or flash, platform within our portfolio really allows us to play across the entire storage landscape.IBD: What do you mean by a third platform?Cordano: The third platform has various elements. One central theme is the buildout of cloud computing, both public and private. Another is mobility, which is becoming sort of a leading driver of the edge, or client. And then there are a number of other threads within that, like the Internet of Things, which is creating machine-generated data.Once you've created these big data repositories in the cloud, new methodologies allow you to derive value and insights from that data. Those are all attributes of this third platform. The previous architectural construct, the second platform, was really client-server technology. We're in the transition from second to third now.IBD: What opportunities does the third platform provide Western Digital?Cordano: Some examples are in the area of mobility and the Internet of Things. Prior to acquiring SanDisk, we had limited exposure to the storage elements of smartphones, or edge sensors in the case of IoT. And now we have exposure to all of those types of products.We're also well-aligned with the people innovating in those areas. So we have a very good view of what's happening, what the storage needs are and what the next-generation products are. We're now participating in those market segments that we were not in prior to the SanDisk acquisition.And if you look at the basic construct in the cloud data center, two storage building blocks are primarily contemplated. One is the enterprise hard drive — an optimized disk drive that is built for the data center, where you get a cost-per-gigabyte advantage. The other major building block is flash, or flash-based storage. So the coupling of those two are really the new building blocks of the cloud data center.One is optimized for cost per gigabyte, which is disk. The other is optimized for cost per I/O, which is a performance measurement — cost per input/output. Depending on the way that application is written, you're going to blend those two technologies in an optimal way to provide capability and performance.IBD: What's the future of disk drives now that chip storage is becoming more pervasive?Cordano: We recognized there was going to be a changing role for disk drives and that, given this transition to the third platform, the fundamental technology was going to change. The role of the hard drive will continue, but it's a changed role.In the data center we see the emergence of this capacity enterprise product line, which is where the growth is, relative to exabytes deployed. We really see the growth in 2020 and beyond to be largely in high-capacity enterprise drives.Historically, Western Digital was primarily in a PC-driven market. That segment of the market is changing as attributes of mobility are more important. The role of nonvolatile memory is playing a more significant role in the PC market. In the markets we serve we see a shifting, changing landscape, where flash is becoming more important in some categories. Disk drives are shrinking in those markets but, as far out as we are planning, we see a role for hard-drive technology, in particular in the data center.IBD: What has the rise of cloud computing meant for Western Digital?Cordano: Its provided multiple levels of opportunity. We've been working directly with large hyper-scale providers for years. That has given us insight into how the tech transitions were going to occur. That was very useful in making plans for products and forming our own strategy. It's been a growth driver. It's also creating a lot of interesting dynamics in the broad IT ecosystem, where things that were more traditionally on premise are moving to the cloud.IBD: How much data can we expect to see crammed into future flash chips?Cordano: What you see is quite interesting. If you look at the capacity growth-rate metrics, solid state is growing roughly at the same rate as disk. If you look at the rate of what we would call areal density, we see that growing in the neighborhood of 25% annualized. That will enable the right balance of cost and performance to support this burgeoning data growth that everyone wants to get access so. Certainly on both technology types the cost per gigabyte is dropping at roughly the same rate.RELATED:Western Digital Draws Praise At First Full-Scale Analyst Meeting In 4 YearsBox CEO Interviewed: Aiming To Change How Businesses Work

The holidays were happy ones for Amazon.com (AMZN), which says that its very own hardware products, led by the Echo Dot, were its best-selling products.Following the Echo Dot, Amazon said the best-selling products over the holiday season overall were the Fire TV Stick, the Fire Tablet and the Amazon Echo.Amazon says it has sold "millions" of the Echo Dot since its introduction. The Echo Dot, which costs $49.99, is the low-end version of the Amazon Echo, which sells for $179.99. The Echo, including Dot, is a voice activated, Wi-Fi-connected smart speaker linked to the cloud. With the voice of the artificially intelligent Alexa, Echo serves up music, news, traffic and weather, plays games, answers questions and does much more.Amazon stock was up 1.5% near 772 in afternoon trading in the stock market today, just below its 50-day moving average.The Amazon Echo, a similar device by the Google unit of Alphabet (GOOGL) and another being developed by Microsoft (MSFT) are expected to play a key role in the smart home. Alphabet recently followed Amazon with the introduction of Google Home, which sells for $129. Google Home is a voice-activated speaker powered by Google Allo, its artificially intelligent assistant.IBD'S TAKE: The battle to provide the best digital butler for homes is one that Amazon and other tech leaders will be fighting for years. These in-home devices with artificial intelligence and language processing skills could evolve into the next major disruption in computing and put the smart home on a fast track.Microsoft has yet to introduce a similar device for the home, but it has deep roots in artificial intelligence with its Cortana platform, available on mobile devices and PCs.
