Intel has an IBD Composite Rating of 75, meaning it performs in the top 25% of all stocks in terms of key metrics. But Micron trails with a low CR of 29.Pitzer reiterated an outperform rating and 20 price target on Micron stock."The rights agreement both helps to facilitate a strategic investment but also acts as a quasi-poison pill given (that it allows) board discretion," he said. "The new agreement increases that possibility of strategic investment or acquisition in the near term."Recent media reports have suggested Micron is in talks to establish a joint venture with China for flash-memory manufacturing and Intel has slowed its Dalian, China, expansion, meaning Micron could be a nice fit for both, Pitzer wrote in a research report.A strategic investment would likely value Micron at $17 to $22 per share. But any such investment by China would likely be capped at 10% and be subject to review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S.China's interest in U.S. semiconductor technology is well-known. Micron reportedly rebuffed a $23 billion unsolicited bid from Chinese Tsinghua Unigroup this year. Tsinghua later tried to invest $3.8 billion at a 15% stake in Western Digital (WDC), a deal hitched on CFIUS review.Micron could also make sense for Intel, which is already a partner on 3D X-Point technology."It could be cheaper for Intel to buy Nand (flash) capacity from Micron than to invest in expanding new capacity at Dalian," Pitzer wrote.

Western Digital (WDC) investor Alken Asset Management is pushing the disk drive maker to send Apple (AAPL) supplier SanDisk (SNDK) back to the sales block, and Western Digital and SanDisk shares split the difference today on Wall Street.Western Digital stock bounded 4.5% on the stock market today, while SanDisk stock slumped 1.7%. The companies' shares have plunged 34% and 10%, respectively, since the $19 billion deal was announced Oct. 21.At the time, the transaction was at a 70% premium to SanDisk's stock price, Alken analyst Vincent Rech wrote in an open letter to Western Digital shareholders."The price being paid for SanDisk is excessive in light of the changing landscape for SanDisk's products and capital markets considerations," he wrote, noting that Western Digital would be forced to take on $14 billion in debt to fulfill the deal."SanDisk, specifically, has suffered significant business challenges recently, causing us to worry as well about paying top dollar for a melting franchise," he added.Since the deal was announced, competition in the Nand (flash memory) field has expanded, squeezing demand, he wrote. Now, a key element of SanDisk's sales is under attack.Hours before Western Digital and SanDisk announced their merger, Intel (INTC) unveiled its $5.5 billion plan to convert its Dalian, China, facility to ramp non-volatile memory. Intel and Micron Technologies (MU) jointly developed 3D Nand and 3D XPoint in 2015.And Tsinghua Unigroup's entrance into the chip industry will only stoke more competitive fires, Rech wrote. The Chinese conglomerate plans to invest $47 billion to become the world's No. 3 chipmaker. To that end, Tsinghua invested $3.8 billion in Western Digital in the month following the SanDisk acquisition plan.Further, SanDisk is dependent on Toshiba for Nand manufacturing. Earlier this month, Toshiba reported its biggest annual loss. And earnings forecasts for SanDisk -- as well as its Nand-rivals Micron, Toshiba, Samsung and SK Hynix -- have dropped 30% since the deal was announced."The market now expects the Nand market to be more competitive -- and profit more elusive -- than the time the transaction was originally negotiated," he wrote.In 2015, SanDisk reported $616 million in operating income -- the lowest level since 2009 -- and well below the $1.5 billion in four of five years that ended Dec. 31, 2014, Rech wrote. Last year, SanDisk suffered from major revenue losses from top customer Apple.Acquiring SanDisk gives Western Digital quick access to the Nand chips needed for its solid-state-drive business, Rech wrote. But that only comprised 7% of Western Digital's total sales in 2015.Alken plans to vote on March 15 against the merger. Should the deal fail, Western Digital would be required to pay SanDisk $185 million.

Micron Technologies (MU) rebuffed Tsinghua Unigroup's $23 billion bid, but that doesn't mean the memory chipmaker has scrapped plans for Chinese partnership, MKM analyst Ian Ing wrote Tuesday in a research report.That partnership could come in the form of a joint venture, Ing wrote in a research report after Micron's analyst day on Friday. Ing reiterated a buy rating and 19 price target on Micron stock, which was up 7.3% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 10.80."We think Micron would require control of both IP and production decisions in the structure of any JV," he wrote. "The biggest benefit to Micron is the ability to produce output as a 'local supplier' and national champion for China's domestic market."China plans to invest $55 billion in local chipmaking businesses by 2020 in an effort to curb reliance on foreign semiconductors. But state-sponsored Tsinghua Unigroup's bid for Micron was doomed from the start, analysts say, as U.S. regulators would have shut it down.A joint venture, however, wouldn't necessarily spike regulators' concerns. Credit Suisse analyst John Pitzer said he "would not be surprised by an equity investment in Micron from one of the Chinese private equity companies."After its failed Micron bid last year, Tsinghua Unigroup invested $3.8 billion in Western Digital (WDC), days before Western Digital announced its plan to acquire flash memory chip maker SanDisk (SNDK)."(Micron) has a presence in all major memory markets, which makes it particularly interesting from M&A or an equity investment target for China Inc.," Pitzer wrote in a report. "While (the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States) could be an issue for outright sale, the company could still attract equity investment in China."Pitzer reiterated his outperform rating and 20 price target on Micron stock. Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan rates Micron stock a buy, with a 21 price target."The backdrop of any buy thesis on Micron over the medium term should be that Samsung is not doing well," Sundararajan wrote in a research report.Apple (AAPL) and Chinese LCD manufacturers are scooping share, and Samsung has yet to squeeze much profit out of its nascent 3D Nand flash chips, he wrote. DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) profitability could be Samsung's "salvation," but its capital expenditures cut has yet to bear fruit. DRAMs are the most common memory chips in computers.Meanwhile, Micron is slimming costs, Sundararajan wrote. In 20-nanometer DRAM, Micron is targeting a cost reduction CAGR (compound annual growth rate) of 15%-25% through fiscal 2017, Pitzer wrote. Micron also sees 25% cost reduction CAGR in 3D Nand."Any progress in closing the cost 'gap' will drive stock performance," Pitzer wrote. A rebound could pull Micron stock out of its trough, Mizuho analyst Vijay Rakesh wrote in a report as he upgraded Micron stock to buy from neutral.Sundararajan also expects Micron to let Intel (INTC) work out the kinks in the jointly-owned 3D X-Point chip and then "exploit it advantageously" from 2018."Good times will come should Micron execute," he wrote. "Micron has dashed hopes and portfolios in 2015, hence it is important to ignore those getting out of Micron stock and take a fresh look."Even with Tuesday's gain, Micron stock is roughly 70% off a nearly 16-year high touched in January 2015.

Stocks opened to thin losses Wednesday, but the Nasdaq flicked in and out of positive territory.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 eased about 0.1% each, with the Nasdaq moving between fractional gains and losses.Things might have been worse in the stock market today, but a strong February employment report from ADP helped shore up some confidence before the start of trade. Still, the market may be hanging back ahead of the Fed's March Beige Book report, due at 2 p.m. ET. It is the last before the Federal Open Market Committee's March 14-15 meeting, and it could have some impact on afternoon trade.Oil prices stuck to their early losses, with West Texas Intermediate down almost 2% and Brent crude trading 1% lower. The Energy Information Administration reports its weekly inventory data at 10:30 a.m. ET. The weekly inventories estimate from the American Petroleum Institute indicated Tuesday that inventories rose 9.9 million barrels last week, vs. consensus views for a 2.5 million barrel increase.Dow stocks opened generally lower. Apple (AAPL), Pfizer (PFE) and Merck (MRK) crept higher, all with gains of less than 0.3%. DuPont (DD) and Nike (NKE) led the downside, with losses of 0.9% and 2%, respectively.On the S&P 500, Monsanto (MON) tumbled 5% after management guided its Q2 and full-year earnings below consensus expectations. Dollar Tree (DLTR) shed 3% after its fourth-quarter earnings fell more than expected and a 117% revenue gain stopped short of analyst forecasts.Small caps were performing comparatively well as the S&P 600 generated some big moves. CheckPoint Systems (CKP) skipped up 27% on a takeover offer. Darling Ingredients (DAR) spiked 26% after reporting Q4 results Tuesday. American Vanguard (AVD) rocketed 16% higher after its Q4 report late Tuesday.On the Nasdaq 100, Seagate Technology (STX) climbed almost 3%. The hard disk drive manufacturer is almost 30% off a Jan. 28 low but still deep in a 15-month consolidation. Peer Western Digital (WDC) rose 2%.Most IBD 50 stocks lost ground in early trade. Ross Stores (ROST) posted the strongest gain, up nearly 3% following its Q4 results late Tuesday.  The gain put shares more than 3% above 55.74 buy point.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks opened moderately higher Thursday as the Nasdaq led.The Dow industrials climbed 0.2%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Nasdaq added 0.4%.Overseas, Europe markets struggled to maintain their rally in afternoon trade. The FTSE 100 in London and CAC 40 in Paris remained up more than 1%. The DAX in Frankfurt, Germany slowed to a 0.5% gain.  Britain's pound rebounded vs. the dollar, narrowly retaking the $1.30 mark.  Markets were buoyed by rising speculation that the Bank of England would trim a quarter point from its target interest rate by the end of next week.China's markets posted an uneven session, with the Shanghai composite marking a flat finish, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 0.7% in a third straight decline.Crude oil continued its bounce, begun midsession Wednesday, with futures up more than 1%. West Texas Intermediate rose to around $48 a barrel.  Gold dimmed to below $1,363 an ounce. The dollar dipped vs. the yen and nudged higher on the euro. U.S. bonds dipped, lifting the 10-year Treasury yield 3 basis points to 1.40%.Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO) jumped 8% at the open after boosting its revenue guidance to 23%-25%, up from prior guidance of 5% to 10%, putting the midpoint well above the consensus estimate. The Taiwan-based chip designer releases full results after the market close July 21.Food packer WhiteWave (WWAV) swelled 19% at the open. France's Danone (DANOY) agreed to buy the Denver-based owner of the Silk, Horizon Organic and Land-O-Lakes brands in a $10 billion deal. Danone said it expects the combination to produce a $300 million increase in operating profit by 2020. Danone shares jumped 2%. WhiteWave peer Hain Celestial Group (HAIN) rocketed 10%.BioMarin Pharmaceuticals (BMRN) popped 8.5%. An agreement announced Monday ended French drugmaker Sanofi's (SNY) effort to acquire Medivation (MDVN), a move that could make BioMarin a potential takeover target.PepsiCo (PEP) rose nearly 3% after reporting second quarter earnings and revenue above analyst views. The snack and drink maker ended Wednesday's session 1% below a 107.04 buy point in a flat base.Hard-drive maker Western Digital (WDC) climbed 5% at the open. The Irvine, Calif.-based company late Wednesday pre-announced fiscal fourth-quarter revenue and earnings above consensus estimates. Peer Seagate Technology (STX) caught some of the updraft, rising 2% at the open.U.S. employers announced 38,536 job cuts in June, up 28% vs. May's layoffs and down 14% vs. year-earlier levels. The report from consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas said eliminations slowed significantly in the second quarter, totaling 132,834 for the quarter. That was down 27% from first-quarter layoffs and 10% below those reported in the second quarter of 2015.The Labor Department reported initial jobless claims declined to 254,000 in the week ended July 2. That was down from an upwardly-revised 270,000 claims in the prior week, and sharply undercutting consensus forecasts for 269,000 claims.Non-farm private employers added 172,000 new works in June, a small step up from the May's 168,000 new hires, according to the ADP National Employment Report.  Economists had projected employers would add 150,000 new positions in June. Services employers hired 208,000 worker during the month, while goods producers saw a net loss of 36,000 positions.At 10:30 a.m. ET, the Energy Information Administration delivers its weekly oil inventories stats.

The stock market was sharply lower with 30 minutet to go in Monday's session as Wall Street pondered the economic implications of last week's Brexit news.Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate (STX) led the Nasdaq 100 lower, falling around 13% and 10%, respectively. American Express (AXP) and DuPont (DD) weighed on the Dow, with losses of around 4% apiece.The Nasdaq slumped 2.7%, the S&P 500 fell 2.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.7%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Friday's levels.The put/call ratio was at 1.23 in late-afternoon trading, indicating excessive fear in the market. Fear has been seen at many market bottoms in the past.Financials were hit hard again, as the Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) slumped about 3%, bringing its two-session decline to 8%. Energy-related industry groups also lagged as benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled at $46.33 a barrel, down nearly 3%.Utilities outperformed. IBD 50 name WEC Energy (WEC) was among a small group of gainers. Shares added close to 2%. B&G Foods (BGS), Dollar General (DG) and CoreSite Realty (COR) also gained.The U.S. dollar rallied for the second straight session, and the British pound fell hard again after hitting a 30-year low Friday. The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield shed another 10 basis points to 1.46%.In the stock market today. Tyler Technologies (TYL) also bucked the downtrend, rising 2%. Breakouts don't have much of a chance in a weak market, but the tech services firm is working on a cup-with-handle base with a 160.69 buy point.Tyler is one of several strong-performing tech services firms. See who the others are with IBD Stock Checkup.Meanwhile, news of a new summer loyalty program didn't help Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG). Shares lost 3% and were down 19% year-to-date.On the downside, European discount airline Ryanair (RYAAY) faced more selling after Friday's 4% haircut. Shares lost an additional 14%.Acuity Brands (AYI) slumped nearly 6% ahead of its earnings report Wednesday before the open.

Oracle (ORCL), Fitbit (FIT), Seagate Technology (STX), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Apple (AAPL) supplier Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) are Tuesday highlights, thanks to a changes in analyst opinion.BMO Capital Markets upgraded the Silicon Valley giant to outperform from market perform and raised its price target to 47 from 45.Shares were up 1.6% Tuesday on the stock market today.The Apple supplier was handed a downgrade to neutral from overweight from JPMorgan. Shares dipped 0.85% to 26.97, still above a 26.68 buy point..In other iPhone chipmaker news, Intel (INTC) might eventually bump off Qualcomm (QCOM) as an iPhone supplier, according to Cowen, which sees Intel grabbing more than half of Apple's iPhone 7 modem business.IBD'S TAKE: Taiwan Semiconductor retook a buy point of 26.68 on Friday. The company had formed a cup-with-handle base and briefly reached that buy point, but then it faltered in the wake of Great Britain's vote to leave the European Union. Shares gapped up above the buy point, past 27, on Monday. To find other high performers, check out IBD's Leaderboard.Wells Fargo initiated the fitness tracker maker with a market perform rating. Shares dropped 1.2% to 13.51.Fitbit was recently named Morgan Stanley's top consumer electronics pick, with analysts from the bank seeing a "strong" holiday season ahead.Shares leapt 21.8% tp 29.35 Tuesday after the hard drive makerannounced preliminary fourth-quarter results and increased revenue guidance for the quarter late Monday.Needham raised its price target to 33 from 31, and Maxim Group boosted its price target to 35 from 25. Needham rates Seagate a buy; Maxim has a hold on the company.Seagate also announced about 6,500 job cuts -- 14% of its global workforce -- by the end of fiscal 2017. Rival Western Digital (WDC) was up 4.8% on the news. Western Digital has been climbing since preannouncing its earnings outlook last week.Stifel resumed coverage of the specialty beauty retailer with a hold rating; shares were up 0.4% to 253.25, hitting a fresh high.Ulta continues to be a high scorer in IBD's ratings, earning a 99 Composite Rating.RELATED:Stock Futures Trade Higher; Seagate, Alcoa, R.R. Donnelley ClimbFitbit Named Morgan Stanley's Top Consumer Electronics Stock Pick

Seagate Technology (STX) enjoyed its best gain in more than four years Tuesday afternoon after the hard drive maker late Monday hiked its earnings guidance and announced a big cut to its workforce.Seagate stock shot up 22% to close at 29.35 in the stock market today, hitting a three-month high. But Seagate remains below its 200-day moving average, which it hasn't crossed since May 2015.Shares of rival Western Digital (WDC) rose 4.8% to 51.84, a six-month high. Western Digital raised earnings guidance earlier this month.Needham raised its price target on Seagate to 33 from 31, with a buy rating. Maxim Group boosted its price target to 35 from 25, with a hold rating.For its fiscal Q4 ended July 1, Seagate now expects revenue of about $2.65 billion, up from previous guidance of $2.3 billion and above the Wall Street consensus estimate of $2.5 billion. That would be down 9.5% from the year-earlier quarter but would mark its best period year over year in the past five quarters.Seagate said the improvement is due to better-than-expected demand for its disk drive products. Market tracker IDC on Monday said global PC shipments fell 4.5% in Q2, but that beat the 7.4% decline it had forecast.While Seagate did not give a specific estimate on earnings per share, it expects a gross profit margin of 25.8%, minus items, up from 23%, which Seagate attributed to "cost containment execution."RBC Capital Market analyst Amit Daryanani said the Seagate guidance implies EPS of 60 cents a share, above the consensus of 40 cents, as polled by Thomson Reuters.Seagate also updated its restructuring plan, saying it will cut 6,500 employees, or 14% of its workforce, by the end of fiscal 2017.On July 7, Western Digital updated EPS guidance to include its recent acquisition of chip storage provider SanDisk. Western Digital completed its $16 billion acquisition of chip-storage provider SanDisk on May 12. With SanDisk, Western Digital becomes a major competitor in both hard disk drives and flash chip storage.Seagate is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 earnings before the market open on Aug. 2.

Micron Technology (MU) stock fell late Tuesday after the No. 5 chipmaker reported fiscal Q1 sales and earnings that missed Wall Street expectations and guided to fiscal Q2 losses for the first time since February 2013.

In after-hours trading, Micron stock was down 5.5% to 14.61 after closing down 1.1% in Tuesday's regular session. Shares are down 58% for the year and on Dec. 14 came within one penny of touching a 27-month low after the company announced an acquisition.
For its fiscal Q1, which ended Dec. 3, Micron reported 24 cents earnings per share minus items on $3.35 billion in sales, down 75% and 25% respectively vs. the year-earlier quarter.

Both measures were in line with Micron's three-months-earlier guidance, but sales missed the $3.46 billion consensus of 34 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. EPS ex items topped Wall Street views for 23 cents.

Micron guided to $2.9 billion-$3.2 billion in sales for fiscal Q2, which would be down 27% at the midpoint of guidance vs. the year-earlier quarter. And for the first time in three years, Micron sees per-share losses: 5-12 cents.
The disappointing Q1 follows Micron's $3.2 billion deal, announced Dec. 14, to acquire the remaining two-thirds of Taiwan chipmaker Inotera Memories. Micron stock fell 3.7% that day.

The planned acquisition is one of the chip sector M&As that will together add up to more than $100 billion this year. Most recently, Intel (INTC) won Chinese regulatory approval to acquire Altera (ALTR) in a $16.7 billion deal expected to close Dec. 28.

Apple (AAPL) supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) expects its $37 billion acquisition of Broadcom (BRCM) to close during Q1. Western Digital's (WDC) $19 billion plan to buy SanDisk (SNDK) is expected to be completed in Q3.

Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.Micron Technology (MU) stock fell late Tuesday after the No. 5 chipmaker reported fiscal Q1 sales and earnings that missed Wall Street expectations and guided to fiscal Q2 losses for the first time since February 2013.In after-hours trading, Micron stock was down 5.5% to 14.61 after closing down 1.1% in Tuesday's regular session. Shares are down 58% for the year and on Dec. 14 came within one penny of touching a 27-month low after the company announced an acquisition.For its fiscal Q1, which ended Dec. 3, Micron reported 24 cents earnings per share minus items on $3.35 billion in sales, down 75% and 25% respectively vs. the year-earlier quarter.Both measures were in line with Micron's three-months-earlier guidance, but sales missed the $3.46 billion consensus of 34 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. EPS ex items topped Wall Street views for 23 cents.Micron guided to $2.9 billion-$3.2 billion in sales for fiscal Q2, which would be down 27% at the midpoint of guidance vs. the year-earlier quarter. And for the first time in three years, Micron sees per-share losses: 5-12 cents.The disappointing Q1 follows Micron's $3.2 billion deal, announced Dec. 14, to acquire the remaining two-thirds of Taiwan chipmaker Inotera Memories. Micron stock fell 3.7% that day.The planned acquisition is one of the chip sector M&As that will together add up to more than $100 billion this year. Most recently, Intel (INTC) won Chinese regulatory approval to acquire Altera (ALTR) in a $16.7 billion deal expected to close Dec. 28.Apple (AAPL) supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) expects its $37 billion acquisition of Broadcom (BRCM) to close during Q1. Western Digital's (WDC) $19 billion plan to buy SanDisk (SNDK) is expected to be completed in Q3.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Trekkies beware: 2016 might be the year of the Borg, and fittingly so, because in the shifting chip landscape, "resistance is futile." Harvard University's Wyss Institute developed organs-on-chips in 2010. Today, the program is more tangible. In 2015, the institute picked up a partnership with Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) for pre-clinical trial testing. And drug companies are taking notice. The…

No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) will breeze through the PC doldrums thanks to Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 7, but rival Advanced Micro Devices' (AMD) three quarters of better-than-expected sales will likely "crack," forcing shares to tumble from four-year highs, analysts said Friday.By the closing bell on the stock market today, Intel shares ended the day up 2.4% to 34, while Advanced Micro Devices stock was up 1.6%, to 5.10. The companies are set to report Q2 earnings on July 20 and July 21, respectively.Intel stock broke out a flat base at a 32.79 buy point on June 23, so it remains within buy range.RBC analyst Amit Daryanani upped his price target on Intel stock to 34 from 33, noting that slightly stronger PC demand and tailwind from Apple's iPhone 7 ramp should provide upside to Intel's fiscal Q2 client computing group (CCG) sales.Intel reportedly will supply a third of Apple's iPhone 7 modems, partially replacing incumbent Qualcomm (QCOM). That could add $300 million to $500 million in incremental sales in the second half of 2016, Daryanani wrote.That will partially offset an expected 7% decline in PC sales in 2016. Intel is the longtime leader in sales of computer microprocessors. It's had a hard time cracking the mobile market, however, so the iPhone 7 win could be big for the company.Daryanani models $30.2 billion in 2016 CCG sales, declining 6.3% but topping a 7.6% fall in 2015. He said Intel's view for accelerating data center sales is likely "aggressive."Still, there's near-term strength in PCs. On Thursday, Western Digital (WDC) upped its fiscal Q4 guidance following its acquisition of SanDisk.Notebook shipments climbed 28% month over month to 9.2 million units in May, according to device makers, Daryanani wrote.Bernstein analyst Stacy Rasgon is less bullish on Intel stock, but boosted his price target to 33 from 26 and upgraded shares to market perform from underperform. He downgraded AMD stock to underperform from market perform and kept his 3 price target.Like Daryanani, Rasgon sees Apple-centric sales boosting Intel's near-term revenue. For Q2, he models $13.6 billion in total sales vs. Wall Street consensus views for $13.5 billion. His Q3 model for $14.6 billion in total sales is largely in line with broader expectations.AMD, on the other hand, is "more controversial," he wrote in a research report. After AMD's Q1 upside surprise, shares rocketed on hopes that share gains vs. Tesla Motors (TSLA) partner Nvidia (NVDA) can hold, that new products might sustain upside and that IP deals may follow.Those hopes are unfounded, Rasgon says. AMD's Q1 upside was likely on channel fill and its semi-custom win was on a console. Also, AMD's Zen product likely won't ramp materially in servers for a year, he says.He wrote that "we suspect downside over the next few quarters is likely, and when it cracks it tends to do it rapidly."

Seagate Technology (STX) announced layoffs, Tractor Supply (TSCO) slashed guidance, Care.com (CRCM) got a big investment from Alphabet (GOOGL)-backed Google Capital and drugmaker Intercept Pharmaceuticals (ICPT) announced a debt offering.Seagate Technology announced plans to cut 1,600 jobs, roughly 3% of its total, as part of a restructuring to lower costs. Hard disk drive makers have been hit hard by the slump in PC sales, as consumers buy more smartphones and tablets. Seagate has reported shrinking earnings for five quarters in a row and analysts project an 84% drop for the current quarter.Seagate expects to complete the restructuring by the end of September and take a $62 million pre-tax charge. Shares were unchanged in extended hours trading in the stock market today after closing up 6.3% at 23.95.Archrival Western Digital (WDC) has also been hard hit by the PC slowdown. Western Digital closed up 5% at 45.60.The operator of about 1,500 retail stores, selling hardware, clothing and agriculture equipment mostly in rural areas, cuts its net sales outlook for the current year to $6.8 billion-$6.9 billion, vs. $6.9 billion-$7 billion earlier. Based on results for the quarter to date, Tractor Supply sees comparable store sales for the current year growing 2.5%-3.5%, down from 3.5%-5%. And it cut its full year diluted EPS forecast to $3.35-$3.40 from $3.40-$3.48. Shares skidded about 7% late after closing up 1%.Google Capital, a venture capital firm backed by Alphabet, bought $46.35 million in new convertible preferred shares from Care.com, a marketplace for managing family care. Care.com closed Wednesday up 2.8% to 8.47, for a $275 million market cap. Care.com leapt to 10 in late trading.Intercept Pharmaceuticals said it plans a $400 million convertible debt offering. Intercept, which is developing liver disease drugs, fell 5% in extended trading. Intercept plans to use part of proceeds to pay for capped call transactions, and to use the remaining proceeds to fund commercialization of its Ocaliva for rare, chronic liver diseases. Intercept closed up fractionally to 149.87 in the regular session.

A Deutsche Bank analyst's October prediction that Micron Technology (MU) will face two "choppy" quarters may come to fruition — the No. 5 chipmaker is expected late Tuesday to report a 75% year-over-year drop in earnings.Analyst Sidney Ho, however, said Micron could be helped by cost tailwinds and potential capital expenditure cuts by competing memory suppliers. Micron stock is down 60% for the year.For its fiscal Q1 ended early this month, Micron is expected to report 23 cents earnings per share ex items on $3.46 billion in sales, down 75% and 24%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier quarter.Three months ago, Micron guided to $3.35 billion to $3.6 billion in sales and 20-26 cents EPS minus items.Micron stock fell 2.7% on Monday, after the chipmaker announced the $3.2 billion deal to acquire Taiwan chipmaker Inotera Memories. But Micron rose 2% for the week, including rising a fraction on Friday.And at least six analysts reiterated buy ratings on Micron stock this week following the Inotera announcement.Per the agreement, Micron will pay 30 New Taiwan dollars, or 92 cents, per Inotera share. Micron already owns 33% of Inotera and the two companies have been memory chip partners for seven years.The acquisition is expected to be immediately accretive to Micron's EPS, free cash flow, gross margins and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization). The companies have 60 days to terminate the agreement.M&As Breach $100 Bil MarkMicron's $3.2 billion Inotera acquisition is just a drop in the $100 billion-plus chip industry M&A bucket for 2015. Big deals included Apple (AAPL) supplier Avago's (AVGO) $37 billion offer for Broadcom and the $19 billion marriage between SanDisk (SNDK) and Western Digital (WDC).Analysts expect the M&A fever to continue into 2016 as the semiconductor industry faces slowing organic growth, rising costs and a limp global economy. Complicating the matter: China wants in on the action and Tsinghua Unigroup has pledged $47 billion to leapfrog Qualcomm (QCOM) to become the No. 3 chipmaker.The Tsinghua push is part of a larger effort by the Chinese government to ease reliance on foreign chips, in part to reduce cybersnooping concerns. Groups in Shanghai and Beijing are making similar efforts, pulling from a $100 billion, government-sponsored pool.This year, Tsinghua Unigroup reportedly made an unsolicited $23 billion bid for Micron. U.S. regulations likely would have stopped the theoretical merger and the offer seems to have fallen off the map.As M&A activity hits new fever pitches in 2016, analysts see smaller chip companies Xilinx (XLNX), Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM) and Cavium (CAVM) as possible takeover candidates.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Altera (ALTR) stock hit a fresh 15-year high Monday after the Chinese Ministry of Commerce approved its acquisition by No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) — the final regulatory obstacle to the transaction. The $16.7 billion acquisition, at about $54 a share, is expected to close Dec. 28, according to 8K filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In morning…

Needham on Wednesday reiterated a strong buy rating on disk drive leader Western Digital (WDC), after Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan acquired company stock valued at $1 million.An SEC filing late Tuesday said Milligan purchased 22,500 shares at a price of $45.53. Insider buying is generally seen as a positive sign.“We believe investors should view this step as a strong vote of confidence in the new trajectory of the company, post the SanDisk acquisition,” wrote Needham analyst Richard Kugele in a research note. “In our view, the purchase also signals that management views the stock to be trading at a depressed valuation.”Western Digital completed its $16 billion acquisition of chip-storage provider SanDisk on May 12.Western Digital stock closed up 2.3% at 47.63 in the stock market today. Shares, though, are down more than 40% since the acquisition agreement was announced in October. Shares hit a four-year low of 34.99 on May 16 but are up 37% since then. Needham's Kugele has a price target of 67 on Western Digital stock.On Friday, Western Digital gave what analysts called a thorough earnings guidance update that appeared to quell concerns about volatility, with the company's light earnings outlook blamed on interest expense on debt. The guidance for the fiscal fourth quarter ending July 1 -- the first to include SanDisk -- beat on the top line but fell well short on the bottom line.With SanDisk, Western Digital becomes a major competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX). SanDisk is among the largest flash-chip storage providers, a market led by Samsung.

Disk drive leader Western Digital (WDC) gave what analysts called a thorough earnings guidance update late Thursday that appeared to quell concerns about volatility, with its light earnings outlook explained as an interest expense on debt.The new guidance for the first time included SanDisk, which Western digital acquired for $16 billion as of May 12. The guidance for its fiscal fourth quarter ending July 1 beat on the top line but fell well short on the bottom line.With SanDisk, Western Digital becomes a major competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX). SanDisk is among a top-tier group of flash-chip storage providers, a market led by Samsung.Western Digital stock finished Friday trading up 1.4% to 44.99 in the stock market today. Shares, though, are down about 45% since the acquisition agreement was announced in October. Shares hit a four-year low of 34.99 on May 16 but are up more than 30% since then.Seagate stock was up 0.5% to 21.66 at the close. The stock is down 21% since the company reported its fiscal Q3 earnings on April 29.Western Digital guided revenue in the range of $3.35-$3.45 billion, slightly above consensus expectations at $3.35 billion. It expects SanDisk to contribute about $750 million for the seven weeks of sales in fiscal Q4. It expects EPS to come in at 65 cents to 70 cents, significantly below the consensus estimate of 90 cents, but the company said that is due to interest costs for its newly issued debt used to finance the SanDisk acquisition.Western Digital held on to previous views for its hard-disk drive business, with revenue of $2.6 billion to 2.7 billion, down about 6% from the prior quarter. Western Digital and Seagate have struggled through the decline in disk drive sales, due largely by the drop in PC sales.“We believe the acquisition of SanDisk is good because Western Digital as a stand-alone disk-drive company is unable to reverse the current earnings headwinds in a declining market,” wrote Rosenblatt Securities analyst Kinngai Chan in a research note.The combination of Western Digital and SanDisk offers a good risk-reward for investors, Chan wrote, as it's better positioned to address the changing industry landscape for storage. That will allow Western Digital to better plan for its shrinking disk drive business, prioritize research and development, and optimize the product roadmap and manufacturing mix, he says.“However, we continue to remain negative on Seagate for the near to medium term as it does not have a good strategy in addressing the declining disk drive market,” Chan wrote.Needham analyst Richard Kugele maintained a strong buy rating on Western Digital stock, but he lowered his price target to 67 from 69.“We believe today begins the resetting of expectations based on the combined company, and should set a base from which to execute and outperform,” Kugele wrote in a research note.RBC Capital analyst Amit Daryanani, in a research note, said Q4 guidance was a step in the right direction and conservative enough to drive upside. He maintained an outperform rating and a price target of 56.While Western Digital didn’t provide any long-term targets for the combined entity, it did take away investor fears of a sharp drop in EPS, Daryanani wrote.“There are still plenty of moving parts that will create a wide dispersion of estimates,” he said.
China's Tsinghua Unigroup has Apple (AAPL) supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) in its sights, planning to invest $47 billion over the next five years to leapfrog Qualcomm and become the world's No. 3 chipmaker.
And Tsinghua's ambitions could find it swallowing up smaller chipmakers such as Maxim Integrated (MXIM), Micron Technology (MU) and Xilinx (XLNX).

The state-owned investment group must outplay U.S. companies scrambling amid frenzied chip sector M&A froth that's busted records in 2015. But its $47 billion strongbox makes battles winnable, Alex Lidow, CEO of privately held power management device maker Efficient Power Conversion, told IBD.

"With a $47 billion war chest, they can do some serious stuff," Lidow said. "You've got companies like Maxim and Xilinx and Micron that are (acquisitions) that would give them immediate, significant market presence in big sectors."
With its resources, Tsinghua "could buy all of them," Lidow said.
Flipping The Paradigm

China plans to flip a longstanding paradigm. The country consumes roughly half the world's $350 billion in chips, but only accounts for 2.5% of the sector's revenue, according to Nanochip Fab Solutions . Chips, in fact, are China's biggest import, says Nanochip.
In June 2014, the government pledged to curb China's reliance on foreign semiconductors.

By 2020, China aims to generate 350 billion yuan ($55 billion) in domestic chip revenue, seeking a compound annual growth rate of 20%. No more than 10 years later, the country wants a top-tier semiconductor company. Thus, the National Semiconductor Industry Investment Fund was born.

Tsinghua is one of 16 shareholders of the fund — a $100 billion pot of which 60% will be directed toward manufacturing acquisitions, according to Semi.org. Groups in Shanghai and Beijing, too, have planned hefty chip investments.

But Tsinghua has been particularly vocal about its goal. Last month, Chairman Zhao Weiguo told Reuters the group will invest $47 billion over five years to become the world's No. 3 chipmaker, behind No. 1 Intel (INTC) and Samsung.
"If you can't be the top-three giant, it will be very hard to develop your business in the chip industry," he told Reuters. "The next five years is key. ... there is an enormous market there."

Intel and Samsung Electronics have market valued near $164 billion and $160 billion, respectively. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) follows in value at $118 billion, but it's a manufacturer that doesn't design its own chips, so it's in a little bit of a different market, with thinner profit margins. Qualcomm is No. 4 in chip company market value, near $73 billion.

"Qualcomm is most at risk because they are already seeing their dominant position in cellphones being challenged, with Samsung and Apple and in the Chinese smartphone market," Lidow said. "They are most vulnerable, for sure."
Tangling With U.S. Government

Tsinghua already has invested billions in chip acquisitions, buying China chipmakers Spreadtrum Communications for $1.8 billion and RDA Microelectronics for $900 million in 2013 and 2014. But getting its hands on a U.S. company is much more difficult, since the U.S. aims to protect its chip industry trade secrets and intellectual property.

In August, Tsinghua made an unsolicited $23 billion bid for Boise, Idaho-based Micron, showing its serious interest in flash memory technology. Wall Street scoffed, saying the U.S. Department of Defense would block that transaction. And the informal bid seemingly has gone nowhere.

"That's one of the reasons Chinese fabs aren't up to par with U.S. fabs, because they're somewhat restricted as to the technology they have access to," Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire told IBD.

The Bureau of Industry and Security tightly controls exports to protect national security and the U.S. economy. Semiconductors are a heavily regulated resource, appearing 41 times on the Bureau's controlled list.
But it's possible Tsinghua found a loophole.

Last month, Tsinghua invested $3.8 billion in Irvine, Calif.-based Western Digital (WDC), a month after Western Digital agreed to buy Milpitas, Calif.-based flash chip maker SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion.
By investing in Western Digital, Tsinghua got itself that much closer to U.S. chip patents, Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan told IBD.
"Tsinghua put in $3.8 billion into Western Digital so they would have SanDisk technology," he said.

China could also make a play for Milpitas, Calif.-based GlobalFoundries, the manufacturing spinoff of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) with fabs in Singapore, Germany and the U.S. Oil-rich Abu Dhabi owns the company and might be looking for a buyer.
To compete with the mature U.S. semiconductor market, Tsinghua "needs to bulk up," Maire said. Fabs such as GlobalFoundries and Taiwan Semiconductor carry significant heft.

"With Micron, U.S. legislators would never let that go through," he said. "But (Tsinghua) could get around (U.S. regulations) and get around the technological hurdles by cutting a deal with GlobalFoundries.
"I wouldn't call it subterfuge, but it would be an interesting back door for China to get its hands on crucial U.S. semiconductor technology."
'Mattson And Chinese Dragon'
Chinese involvement aside, 2015 marked a record M&A year for the rapidly consolidating semiconductor industry. The trend looks to continue in 2016, Lidow said.

"Just about any of the second- and third-tier semiconductors are probably going to be involved in M&A activity over the next couple of years — Cypress Semiconductor (CY), Micron, GlobalFoundries, Maxim, Xilinx," he said.
Maire also cites Axcelis Technologies (ACLS), Rudolph Technologies (RTEC), Nanometrics (NANO), Nova Measuring (NVMI) and Ultratech (UTEK) as potential acquisition targets.

Chip giants Texas Instruments (TXN), Intel and Samsung are safe — for the time being, Lidow said. He estimates it would take a Chinese company five years after a major acquisition to make any dominant inroads in the semiconductor world.

Beijing-based E-Town Dragon Semiconductor Industry Investment Center, not Tsinghua, has already begun its efforts on that cycle, this month announcing an agreement to acquire Mattson Technology (MTSN), a maker of chip-manufacturing gear based in Fremont, Calif., for $12.2 million.

Acquiring Mattson is just a drop in the "proverbial bucket," Maire wrote in a research report. E-Town's plans remain veiled, but regulators will likely approve the acquisition, as "Mattson has no advanced technology the U.S. government would be concerned about," he wrote.

"It will be an interesting test as this is the first Chinese acquisition of a U.S. semiconductor company," Maire wrote. But "this is not a very bold start, buying the worst equipment company as compared to the very bold bid by the Chinese to buy Micron."
He added: "Even if the Micron bid was doomed from the start, it was certainly headline grabbing."

Apple (AAPL) supplier NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) muscled by completing its $12 billion acquisition of smaller peer Freescale Semiconductor, making it No. 5 by market value in IBD's 46-company Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group.
With a $20.4 billion market cap, NXP trails only Qualcomm (QCOM), Avago Technologies (AVGO), Broadcom (BRCM) — all fellow Apple suppliers — and ARM Holdings (ARMH) .

In late-afternoon trading on the stock market today, NXP stock was up nearly 2%, near 88. Freescale stock closed down 1.5%, at 36.53, on Monday, its last day of trading on the NYSE. NXP stock fell 4.6% on Monday.
The companies announced the closing of their deal on Monday. The merger was announced in March, heralding a record-busting year for chip industry M&As.
In May, Avago agreed to buy Broadcom for $37 billion. A month later, Intel (INTC) announced that it had inked a $16.7 billion deal to buy Altera (ALTR) .
On a single day in October, Western Digital (WDC) agreed to buy SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion, and chip gear maker Lam Research (LRCX) put up a $10.6 billion bid for rival KLA-Tencor (KLAC).

Last month, On Semiconductor (ON) agreed to buy Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) for $2.4 billion. Meanwhile, Microsemi (MSCC) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) battled it out for PMC-Sierra (PMCS) for over a month before Microsemi won with a $2.5 billion offer.
Combined, NXP and Freescale expect $10 billion in annual sales. The merged company has 45,000 employees — including 11,000 engineers — and 9,000 patent families, according to an NXP overview.
NXP says that it expects to be No. 1 in communications processors, secure identification, broad-based microcontrollers, radio-frequency transistors, automotive chips and small-signal discretes.
In 2020, NXP aims to ship 40 billion connected devices in areas such as secure ID and mobile transactions.

Together, NXP and Freescale plan to lead the industry in chips for payment cards, point-of-sale terminals, transport ticketing, closed loop payment and mobile transactions, according to the company's plan.

Today, "90% of auto innovation" is within electronics, according to NXP. The company says that it plans to lead the industry in terms of infotainment, vehicle networking, body, safety and secure access.

Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.Apple (AAPL) supplier NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) muscled by completing its $12 billion acquisition of smaller peer Freescale Semiconductor, making it No. 5 by market value in IBD's 46-company Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group.With a $20.4 billion market cap, NXP trails only Qualcomm (QCOM), Avago Technologies (AVGO), Broadcom (BRCM) — all fellow Apple suppliers — and ARM Holdings (ARMH) .In late-afternoon trading on the stock market today, NXP stock was up nearly 2%, near 88. Freescale stock closed down 1.5%, at 36.53, on Monday, its last day of trading on the NYSE. NXP stock fell 4.6% on Monday.The companies announced the closing of their deal on Monday. The merger was announced in March, heralding a record-busting year for chip industry M&As.In May, Avago agreed to buy Broadcom for $37 billion. A month later, Intel (INTC) announced that it had inked a $16.7 billion deal to buy Altera (ALTR) .On a single day in October, Western Digital (WDC) agreed to buy SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion, and chip gear maker Lam Research (LRCX) put up a $10.6 billion bid for rival KLA-Tencor (KLAC).Last month, On Semiconductor (ON) agreed to buy Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) for $2.4 billion. Meanwhile, Microsemi (MSCC) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) battled it out for PMC-Sierra (PMCS) for over a month before Microsemi won with a $2.5 billion offer.Combined, NXP and Freescale expect $10 billion in annual sales. The merged company has 45,000 employees — including 11,000 engineers — and 9,000 patent families, according to an NXP overview.NXP says that it expects to be No. 1 in communications processors, secure identification, broad-based microcontrollers, radio-frequency transistors, automotive chips and small-signal discretes.In 2020, NXP aims to ship 40 billion connected devices in areas such as secure ID and mobile transactions.Together, NXP and Freescale plan to lead the industry in chips for payment cards, point-of-sale terminals, transport ticketing, closed loop payment and mobile transactions, according to the company's plan.Today, "90% of auto innovation" is within electronics, according to NXP. The company says that it plans to lead the industry in terms of infotainment, vehicle networking, body, safety and secure access.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Amid slowing growth in smartphone sales, ARM Holdings is going to great lengths to tap new markets. The Cambridge, England-based chip designer is hiring hundreds of R&D engineers and acquiring companies and patents to develop next-generation technology. Through the first three quarters of the year, ARM (ARMH) has hired 559 employees, on top of the 441 it put on the…
Applied Materials (AMAT) stock reversed a down-day Thursday on Wall Street after reporting fiscal Q4 sales that topped analyst projections.
In early after-hours trading, Applied Materials stock was up 3.5%. Shares closed down 1.5% in regular-session trading ahead of the No. 1 chip gear-maker's scheduled quarterly earnings report.
For its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 25, Applied Materials reported 29 cents earnings per share ex items on $2.37 billion in sales, both measures up 7% vs. the year-earlier quarter.

Sales topped the consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which saw $2.4 billion. Applied Materials' 29-cent EPS met the consensus and was the company's second-highest earning quarter behind Q3.
Three months ago, Applied Materials guided to a 7%-to-flat decline in sales vs. Q3 sales of $2.5 billion. The company also saw 27-31 cents EPS minus items.
Fiscal 2015 sales of $9.7 billion, up 6% year over year, and $1.19 EPS ex items, up 11% vs. the year-ago quarter, also narrowly beat the consensus — which saw $9.6 billion and $1.18.
For the current quarter, Applied Materials sees revenue falling 2-9% sequentially and 23-27 cents EPS. In the year-ago quarter, the company reported 23 cents EPS on $2.2 billion in sales.

Applied Materials is in IBD's 36-member Electronic-Semiconductor Equipment industry group. The company has a middling Composite Rating of 49 out of a best-possible 99. Lam Research (LRCX) tops the group with a CR of 91.

Lam might also swipe Applied Materials' No. 1 slot in the chip gear-making sector with the recently announced acquisition of KLA-Tencor (KLAC) (CR of 85), Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire theorized in a recent research report.
Or, Applied Materials could make a play for KLA by topping Lam's $10.6 billion bid.
"We have to admit that our first reaction to the announcement of the Applied Materials/Tokyo Electron deal was shock that Applied Materials didn't make a play for KLA first," Maire wrote.
The Tokyo Electron deal floundered for nearly two years before it died in the water.

Lam and KLA announced their merger as Western Digital (WDC) confirmed rumors by making a $19 billion play for SanDisk (SNDK), beating out potential interest from Micron Technology (MU) and Seagate Technology (STX) amid mass chip sector consolidation.
KLA's process control operations are superior to Applied Materials' operations, Maire wrote.

"It's more synergistic and, perhaps more importantly, blocks Lam or ASML Holding (ASML) from getting their hands on this crown jewel in the industry," he wrote. "Bottom line, KLA is worth jumping through hoops for."

Today's IBD International Leaders screen of top rated global stocks includes three highly rated chipmakers. Two Apple suppliers make the list — Avago Technologies (AVGO) and ARM Holdings (ARMH) — as well as fabless semiconductor company Silicon Motion Technology[ticker…

Following up on its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk, Western Digital (WDC) issued new quarterly guidance after the market close Thursday that beat on the top line but fell well short on the bottom line.Western Digital announced the completion of its SanDisk acquisition two weeks ago, creating a big competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.Reflecting the ownership of SanDisk as of May 12, Western Digital now expects revenue of $3.35 billion to $3.45 billion for its fiscal Q4 ended July 1, compared with its earlier forecast of $2.6 billion to $2.7 billion. The midpoint is above the consensus estimate among analysts of $3.35 billion, as polled by Thomson Reuters. Western Digital reported revenue of $3.19 billion in the year-earlier quarter. That would be up 6.6% at the midpoint, where Western Digital revenue has declined the past six quarters year over year.It expects earnings per share minus items of 65 cents to 70 cents, compared with its earlier guidance of $1 to $1.10 a share. Analysts, though, had modeled EPS ex items of 90 cents.Western Digital stock was down more than 1% in after-hours trading, after rising a fraction in Thursday's regular session, to 44.38. Through Thursday's close, shares are down 45% since the acquisition agreement was announced in October. Shares hit a four-year low of 34.99 on May 16 but are up about 25% since then.Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX).Seagate stock closed at 21.55, up a fraction. The stock is down 21% since the company reported its fiscal Q3 earnings on April 29.Western Digital and SanDisk had combined revenue of about $20 billion in 2015.SanDisk is a leading provider of chips used for data storage in a wide variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets and PCs. The deal will help SanDisk, which has a strong retail business, move up the ladder to make bigger sales to businesses and other enterprise customers -- the market where Western Digital is strongest. Western Digital gets the ability to offer chip-based storage in areas where its disk-drive technology is losing ground.

Western Digital (WDC) will provide revenue and earnings guidance for the first time since completing its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk.Western Digital announced the completion of its SanDisk acquisition on Thursday, creating a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.The company says it will update its guidance on May 26, after the market close, for its fiscal fourth quarter ending July 1. The guidance will reflect the partial period of ownership of SanDisk in Q4.RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani, in a research note, said he expects Western Digital to imply Q4 revenue guidance of $3.4 billion. That’s above the consensus estimate of $3.34 billion from analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.The Wall Street consensus on earnings per share minus items is 86 cents. Daryanani expects 93 cents. He has an outperform rating on Western Digital stock and a price target of 56.Western Digital was trading near 39, up 5%, in afternoon trading in the stock market today. But shares are down more than 20% since the company's posted fiscal Q3 earnings on April 28.Western Digital and SanDisk had combined revenue of about $20 billion in 2015. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX).Seagate was trading near 20, up 4%, Wednesday afternoon. The stock is down 24% since the company reported its fiscal Q3 earnings on April 29.SanDisk is a leading provider of chips used for data storage in a wide variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets and PCs. The deal will help SanDisk, which has a strong retail business, move up the ladder to make bigger sales to businesses and other enterprise customers -- the market where Western Digital is strongest. Western Digital gets the ability to offer chip-based storage in areas where its disk drive technology is losing ground.

Western Digital (WDC) on Tuesday received a price-target hike to 50 from 45 and an upgrade to outperform from market perform by Cowen analyst Karl Ackerman.The moves comes two days before Western Digital is slated to give new guidance that will include its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk. Western Digital announced the completion of its SanDisk acquisition last week, creating a big competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage. The company has said it would update its guidance after the market close Thursday for its fiscal fourth quarter ending July 1.Ackerman says while he expects the SanDisk acquisition to dilute earnings through 2017, “We think the stock should start to work higher from here, as Western Digital’s updated guidance should act as a positive catalyst and help eliminate uncertainty."Western Digital stock finished trading up 4.5% to 42.28 in the stock market today. However, the stock is down 47% since the acquisition was announced in October. Shares hit a four-year low of 34.99 on May 16 but are up 20% since then.Western Digital and SanDisk had combined revenue of about $20 billion in 2015, with $14.5 billion from Western Digital. It’s the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX).SanDisk is a leading provider of chips used for data storage in a wide variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets and PCs. The deal will help SanDisk, which has a strong retail business, move up the ladder to make bigger sales to businesses and other enterprise customers -- the market where Western Digital is strongest. Western Digital gets the ability to offer chip-based storage in areas where its disk drive technology is losing ground.Western Digital's year-over-year revenue has fallen for six straight quarters. That’s largely due to lower disk drive sales in the slumping PC market and the migration of disk storage to chip-based storage in many products. Seagate's revenue has fallen for five straight quarters.“Now that SanDisk is subsumed into Western Digital’s operations, Western Digital now morphs from an enterprise highly exposed to the cannibalization of next-generation storage into a media agnostic, vertically integrated data storage provider capable of generating mid-single-digit revenue growth and low-double-digit EPS growth,” Ackerman wrote.He said the top 10 customers shared between Western Digital and SanDisk include Best Buy (BBY), Apple (AAPL), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc. (HPQ)“With SanDisk, Western Digital can now more effectively service both enterprise and hyper-scale customers and capitalize on the explosion of data creation that should double every two to three years by 2020," Ackerman wrote.

Capital spending on cloud computing infrastructure by Apple (AAPL) and U.S. Internet companies has slowed as Chinese companies, led by Alibaba (BABA), come on stronger, says RBC Capital in a research report.Apple's September-quarter cloud spending slipped 5% to $3.6 billion, while Alibaba's jumped 64%, albeit from a lower base, to $197 million, says RBC Capital.Apple has expanded its data center capacity to deliver more Web services to consumers, especially via mobile devices. RBC Capital's figures, though, include spending on retail stores as well, since Apple does not separate the two areas.Apple, Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, Microsoft (MSFT) and Amazon.com (AMZN) account for 75% of spending in RBC's cloud capital spending survey. Facebook (FB), eBay (EBAY) and China's Alibaba, Baidu (BIDU) and Tencent account for an additional 15% of the spending, says RBC analyst Amit Daryanani in the report.He says cloud capital spending by six Chinese companies tracked in the survey rose 71% in the September quarter to $1.1. billion. Alibaba and other Chinese e-commerce firms reported record numbers for their Singles Day shopping event on 11/11.Based on consensus estimates, cloud capital spending overall in 2015 will rise just 6.7% to $43.8 billion, says Daryanani, slowing from 2014's 29% growth rate. Based on current estimates, Wall Street is modeling for a rebound in 2016 to 13% growth, says the RBC analyst.He notes, however, that U.S. Internet companies have not provided 2016 guidance.The RBC Capital analyst follows companies that sell products for cloud infrastructure, including Intel (INTC), Avago (AVGO) and Western Digital (WDC).

Apple's (AAPL) iPhone "elephant in the room" clouded Qorvo's (QRVO) otherwise upbeat analyst day, an MKM analyst wrote late Tuesday as he suggested that the chipmaker might be considering a hefty M&A play.Qorvo stock closed up 5.6% in the stock market today at 54.74.March-quarter expectations for a 10%-15% depression in iPhone sales remained unchanged, MKM analyst Ian Ing noted in a research report. Ing retired his 71 price target and buy rating on Qorvo stock."With the iPhone 'elephant in the room,' we felt investor concerns regarding a smartphone unit slowdown remained only partially addressed and not in Qorvo's control," Ing wrote.Slower growth rates are still likely out of China, he added.But Qorvo's overall outlook was positive, Ing wrote. The company revised its long-term target model to 32%-35% vs. an earlier 30% target and outlined plans to recapture Samsung and MediaTek smartphone share in China.A recent $1 billion debt issuance could signal that Qorvo's Industrial and Defense Products segment is becoming acquisitive, Ing wrote. Strategic M&A could help Qorvo's IDP business grow at twice the industry's 7% growth rate.Qorvo would merely be the latest in a series of recently acquisitive chip companies. Last month, Lam Research (LRCX) agreed to acquire KLA-Tencor (KLAC), a combination that might overtake Applied Materials' (AMAT) market share, and Western Digital (WDC) made a bid for SanDisk (SNDK).Earlier this year, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR), and Avago Technologies (AVGO) announced its plan to acquire Broadcom (BRCM).Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Microsemi (MSCC) and Apple (AAPL) supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) grappled again Wednesday for chipmaker PMC-Sierra (PMCS) amid frenzied industry consolidation that also saw On Semiconductor (ON) agree to buy Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS). On Semiconductor put up a $2.4 billion bid for Fairchild Semiconductor, announced early Wednesday. On Semiconductor stock fell 7.9% in the stock market today on the news, while…

Western Digital (WDC) completed its $16 billion acquisition of SanDisk, creating a formidable competitor in both disk drives and flash-chip storage.SanDisk is a leading provider of chips used for data storage in a wide variety of devices, including smartphones, tablets and PCs. The deal will help SanDisk, which has a strong retail business, move up the ladder to make bigger sales to businesses and other enterprise customers, the market where Western Digital is strongest. Western Digital gets the ability to offer chip-based storage in areas where its disk drive technology is losing ground.Western Digital didn't provide updated guidance with its announcement of the deal's closure."This is disappointing, as the company indicated on its earnings call, perhaps unintentionally, that it planned to provide updated June guidance when the deal closed,” Pacific Crest Securities analyst Weston Twigg wrote in a research note. Western Digital did say that it would provide guidance in the "near term."Twigg said Western Digital should remain well positioned in its core hard disk drive business, though disk drive revenue will decline over the next five years as non-volatile memory and software-optimized storage products gain.“Western Digital's acquisition of SanDisk should help position it for these shifts,” Twigg wrote.Western Digital and SanDisk had combined revenue of about $20 billion in 2015. Western Digital is the largest provider of disk drives, ahead of Seagate Technology (STX)."This transformational combination creates a media-agnostic leader in storage technology with a robust portfolio of products and solutions that will address a wide range of applications in almost all of the world’s computing and mobile devices,” Western Digital CEO Steve Milligan said in Friday's press release announcing the acquisition had closed.Sanjay Mehrotra, co-founder and CEO of SanDisk, will serve as a member of the Western Digital board of directors.Western Digital stock was down 2.5%, near 35, in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today, at a more than three-year low. Seagate stock was up 1.5%, near 19, after touching a four-year low on Thursday.

Stock futures narrowed their early gains on the approach to Friday's preholiday weekend session, as investors tussled with earnings and merger news and revised GDP data.Nasdaq 100 futures pared gains to less than 0.2% above fair value. Dow industrials and S&P 500 futures held gains of less than 0.1% each. Small caps were a weak spot, with Russell 2000 futures slipping in and out of fractional losses.The stock market today looks to close out what has so far been a week of improvement for the market. The Nasdaq heads into the session up 2.8% and back above its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 opens with a 1.8% gain for the week. It is the best performance since the week ended April 1 and a second straight advance for both indexes.Apple (AAPL) slipped more than 1% early Friday, weighing on the Dow and the Nasdaq 100. Western Digital (WDC) dropped 1.4%, also dragging on the Nasdaq after lowering its fiscal Q4 EPS and revenue guidance based on its acquisition of SanDisk.Veeva Systems (VEEV) swept up 9% in premarket action. The medical software maker reported late Thursday that both earnings and revenue cleared analyst estimates, and management lifted second-quarter and full-year revenue guidance above forecasts. Shares ended Thursday 6% above a 28.05 buy point from a cup-with-handle base after a low-volume breakout in mid-May.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) also scrambled 9% higher after reporting its first-quarter results late Thursday. The Bolingbrook, Ill.-based chain reported earnings up 39% on a 24% jump in revenue. Both easily cleared consensus targets. Comparable-store sales surged 15%.Management's second-quarter earnings guidance was below expectations, but revenue guidance was better than expected. Ulta shares have been nibbling away at new highs and ended Thursday extended 13% past a 188.58 buy point.Outside the IBD 50, Big Lots (BIG) muscled out a 13% premarket advance. Its first-quarter earnings blew past expectations, and revenue growth topped by a narrow margin. The stock's premarket move implies an open back above a 46.23 buy point, which the stock had initially topped in April.GameStop (GME) ripped 6% lower after reporting its Q2 results after Thursday’s close.In some random moves, not related to earnings, homebuilder Pulte Group (PHM) powered up nearly 6% in premarket trade. Liberty Global (LBTYK) popped 5%Heavy equipment maker Terex (TEX) plunged 18% lower after China's Zoomlion called off its $3.4 billion acquisition bid.Embattled drug maker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) scaled up 6% after announcing it had rejected a joint takeover bid from Japan's Takeda Pharmaceuticals and private equity outfit TPG.The Commerce Department revised its first-quarter GDP growth estimate slightly higher, to 0.8%, vs. and initial estimate of a 0.5% increase. It eased its inflation estimate slightly, pulling the GDP Price Index back to a 0.6%, from an original 0.7% increase.The University of Michigan serves up its final reading on Consumer Sentiment for May. Baker Hughes' (BHI) weekly rig count is due out at 1 p.m. ET, and Janet Yellen joins a discussion about interest rates at Harvard University at 1:15 p.m.Crude oil trimmed early losses to less than 1%, putting West Texas Intermediate just above $49 a barrel and up about 6% for the week. Gold was essentially flat at $1,220 an ounce, 4% below last Friday's settlement. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro, down vs. the yen, and bonds held steady.

Inphi (IPHI) stock gapped up Wednesday on Wall Street after the chipmaker reported Q3 earnings that, for the eighth consecutive quarter, more than doubled year over year.And at least one analyst now sees Inphi as a potential M&A target.For its fiscal Q3 ended Sept. 30, Inphi reported 25 cents earnings per share ex items, up 108% year over year, and above the consensus which modeled 24 cents. Three months ago, Inphi guided to between 22 cents and 26 cents.Although Inphi has more than doubled its EPS in each of the last eight quarters, Q3 was the fourth in a row showing deceleration.Revenue of $62.4 million, up 72%, also beat the consensus of 12 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which saw $61.3 million. Inphi previously guided to $59 million to $63.6 million.In the current quarter, Inphi expects 25 cents to 27 cents EPS on $63.3 million to $65.3 million in sales. Sales would be up 17% at the midpoint while earnings would fall 13% at the midpoint vs. the year-earlier quarter.At least five analysts boosted their price targets on Inphi stock on Wednesday.Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan rates Inphi stock a buy and issued a price target of 31. He was "cautiously optimistic" on Inphi's return to business in China.Inphi CEO Ford Tamer said Tuesday that the chipmaker saw depressed Q2 mobile sales out of China reverse in Q3."We have seen a resumption of the China demand," Tamer told analysts during the Q3 earnings conference call. "We feel confident that Phase II of the China mobile infrastructure has resumed. So, based on the data we have today, we're seeing obviously orders flowing back in."Sundararajan sees "significant chances that Inphi could become a target of acquisition." M&A action within the chip industry hit a fever pitch this year with the multibillion-dollar acquisition deals selling SanDisk (SNDK) to Western Digital (WDC), KLA-Tencor (KLAC) to Lam Research (LRCX), Altera (ALTR) to Intel (INTC) and Broadcom (BCRM) to Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO).Inphi stock carries a high IBD Composite Rating of 97 out of a best-possible 99 in its Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless group, putting it alongside other top-performing stocks like Integrated Device Technology (IDTI), ARM Holdings (ARMH), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Cavium (CAVM).Cavium stock, set to report its fiscal Q3 after the close Wednesday, was up nearly 1.5% in early trading. Integrated Device Technology stock, which beat forecasts in its Q2 report and announced an acquisition Tuesday, was up more than 3%.In morning trading on the stock market today, Inphi stock was up nearly 8%, trading near 30.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Stocks opened to thin losses Tuesday, but quickly retrenched into narrowly mixed action. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were positive, up less than 0.1% each. The Dow Jones industrial average hung 0.1% into the red, weighed down by IBM's (IBM) 5% loss.
Volume was narrowly mixed, 2% higher on the NYSE and down 4% on the Nasdaq, relative to trade early Monday.

The stock market today received mixed signals before the open from September housing data, which showed housing starts up more than 6% for the month, while permits for future building projects slowed. Apartment projects accounted for a large share of the jump in starts, which thinned the surprise a bit. But it was still the first month-over-month gain in three months and held the annualized pace of starts above 1 million, a healthy sign.
Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen is scheduled to speak at 11 a.m. ET.

Among the morning's headline stock moves, memory chipmaker SanDisk (SNDK) flashed 7% higher after news reports outlined late-stage discussions of a possible acquisition by Western Digital (WDC). The companies were discussing a price between 80 and 90 per share, according to unnamed sources quoted by Bloomberg, a premium of 11% to 25% over SanDisk's closing price on Monday. The reports said a deal could be reached this week. Monday's gain put shares 74% above an August low and 28% below a December high. Western Digital shares slumped more than 3%. SanDisk reports Q3 results after Wednesday's close.

Monster Beverage (MNST) climbed nearly 5%, punching back above its 10-week moving average in powerful trade. The stock has been living below its 10-week line since late August and is attempting to climb the right side of an 11-week consolidation.
Among leaders, Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) popped 3% in heavy trade. The gain moved the Little Rock, Ark.-based outfit out of buying range above a 45.25 cup-with-handle buy point.

At the opposite end of the IBD 50 list, Hawaiian (HA) pared losses to less than 2% after dropping more than 5% at the start of trade. The island-hopping airline reported Q3 earnings above expectations. Revenue slipped less than forecast.
A busy after-hours session includes scheduled earnings reports from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Yahoo (YHOO), Illumina (ILMN) and Cree (CREE).
